europeana:record.dc:title: The ingenious hidalgo Don Quixote of La Mancha
El ingenioso hidalgo don Quixote de la Mancha
europeana:record.dc:creator: Cervantes Saavedra, Miguel de (1547-1616)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Literatura
europeana:record.dc:description: It was in 1829 when Vicente Salvá determined that this was the true edicio princeps of El ingenioso hidalgo don Quijote de la Mancha (The Ingenious Gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha), as up until that point it was considered to be a second edition, printed that same year. In the copy kept in the Biblioteca Nacional, the cover and four preliminary pages, which did not exist when it arrived in 1865, were replaced by photolithographic copies from the copy belonging to the Real Academia Española (Royal Spanish Academy), made by López Fabra. Printing began at the end of September 1604, close to the date of the licence, and some copies were even printed in Valladolid. They were sold previously at court in Madrid, where they came out in January 1605. This copy which is kept in the Biblioteca Nacional was received in 1865 from a private donor, as Hartzenbusch says in his Report as director of the Library from the same year.

Fue en 1829 cuando Vicente Salvá determinó que esta era la verdadera edición príncipe de El ingenioso hidalgo don Quijote de la Mancha, ya que hasta entonces se había tenido como tal una segunda edición, impresa el mismo año. En el ejemplar conservado en la Biblioteca Na cional, la portada y cuatro hojas de preliminares, de los que carecía cuando ingresó en 1865, fueron sustituidas por reproducciones fotolitográficas del ejemplar de la Real Academia Española, realizadas por López Fabra. La impresión comenzó a finales de septiembre de 1604, fecha cercana a la del privilegio, e incluso algunos ejemplares se imprimieron en Valladolid, vendiéndose antes en la corte que en Madrid, donde salieron a la luz en enero de 1605. Este ejemplar que alberga la Biblioteca Nacional ingresó en 1865 como donativo de un particular, según cuenta Hartzenbusch en su Memoria del mismo año como director de la Biblioteca.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: Con Priuilegio de Castilla, Aragon y Portugal en Madrid por Iuan de la Cuesta vendese en casa de Francisco Robles, librero del Rey nro señor

europeana:record.dc:title: Balsas sirdies pas Wieszpati Diewa, panna swenciause Maria ir jo swentus danguy karalaujancius szaukiancios, per giesmes pagal iszpažinimo bažnicios swentos katalickos Rimo sudetas
europeana:record.dc:creator: Šrubauskis, Pranciškus
europeana:record.dc:subject: 240 Christian moral & devotional theology
europeana:record.dc:description: This book was one of the most popular seventeenth century Catholic hymn books in the Lithuanian language. "Balsas sirdies" (The Voice of the Heart) distinguished from other works by its view of the nature of the Baroque epoch and its intertwining with the medieval literary tradition. Sadly, the first edition (published around 1680) has been lost. The earliest surviving copy is the 1726 edition published in the printing house of the Vilnius Jesuit Academy. Two examples of this publication are held in Krakow and Vilnius. The book is stored at The Wroblewski Library of the Lithuanian Academy of Sciences.

Ši knyga yra vienas populiariausių XVII a. katalikiško giesmyno lietuvių kalba leidinių. Pirmoji šio giesmyno laida, išėjusi apie 1680 m., neišliko. Ankstyviausios išlikusios laidos egzempliorius yra 1726 m. Vilniaus jėzuitų Akademijos spaustuvės leidinys. Žinomi išlikę du šio leidinio egzemplioriai: vienas Krokuvoje, kitas Vilniuje. Giesmyno „Balsas širdies“ specifika – Baroko epochos pasaulėjauta, susipinanti su Viduramžių literatūros tradicija. Šis leidinys saugomas Lietuvos mokslų akademijos Vrublevskių bibliotekoje.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: Wilno, w druk. Akademie Soc. Jesu
europeana:record.dc:source: The Wroblewski Library of the Lithuanian Academy of Sciences

europeana:record.dc:title: 29 Discourses of the Pious Isaia Pustnicul: manuscript
29 de Cuvintări ale Cuviosului Isaia Pustnicul
europeana:record.dc:creator: Isaia Pustnicul
europeana:record.dc:subject: 090 Manuscripts & rare books
europeana:record.dc:description: The Discourses were written by Isaia Pustnicul who lived in the V century and was known as a great spiritual father called “the cleverest among the clever”. The speeches treat the virtues of ascetic life, and are addressed to young monks. The manuscript has been included in the Register of the National Programme “The Memory of Moldova”, the section “Patrimonial documents of national importance stored in the territory of Moldova”.

Manuscrisul cu titlul "29 de Cuvântări ale Cuviosului Isaia Pustnicul", care a trăit în veacul al V-lea, cunoscut ca un mare Părinte duhovnicesc, numit "înţeleptul, între înţelepţi". Aceste cuvântări, adresate tinerilor monahi, tratează despre virtuţile principale ale vieţii ascetice.
În acest exemplar lipseşte Cuvântarea cu nr. 21. Textul manuscrisului deţinut de BNRM diferă de cel publicat în: "Filocalia sau culegere din scrierile sfinţilor părinţi care arată cum se poate curăţi, lumina şi desăvîrşi. Vol. XII: Cuviosul Isaia Pustnicul douăzeci şi nouă de cuvinte", tradusă din greceşte cu introducere şi note de Dumitru Stăniloae, membru al Acad. Române şi editată în 1991 la Bucureşti.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: National Library of the Republic of Moldova
europeana:record.dc:source: National Library of the Republic of Moldova

europeana:record.dc:title: Church Prayer Book
Ceasoslov
europeana:record.dc:subject: 090 Manuscripts & rare books
europeana:record.dc:description: The Big Church Prayer Book was published at Dubasari in 1794 by M. Strilbitki who was a publisher, editor and engraver. In Moldova there are four editions of this document: three editions at the National Library of the Republic of Moldova, and one edition at the Museum of Romanian Literature. The National Library owns the edition which is in a better state than the others. The only shortcoming of the book is that pages 789-814 are missing. The manuscript has been included in the Register of the National Programme “The Memory of Moldova”, section “Patrimonial documents of national importance stored in the territory of Moldova.

Ceasoslov Mare editat la Dubăsari în 1794 de M. Strilbiţki (tipograf, editor şi gravor din Moldova). în republică există 4 exemplare (3 exemplare - BNRM şi un exemplar - Muzeul Literaturii Române), dintre care unicul exemplar cu o stare de conservare satisfăcătoare (lipsesc pp. 789-814) se păstrează în colecţiile BNRM.
Incluse în Registrul Programului Naţional „Memoria Moldovei" (compartimentul „Documente patrimoniale păstrate în teritoriul Republicii Moldova de importanţă naţională").
europeana:record.dc:publisher: National Library of the Republic of Moldova
europeana:record.dc:source: National Library of the Republic of Moldova

europeana:record.dc:title: The Prophecy, vision and divine revelation revealed by the very humble prophet Jehan Michel
La prophécie, vision et révélacion divine révélée par très humble prophète Jehan Michel
europeana:record.dc:creator: Michel, Jean (1430?-1501)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Canards (journalisme)
europeana:record.dc:description: Jean Michel, who called himself a "very poor and humble beggar" but has sometimes been identified as the personal physician of King Charles VIII (1470-1498), wrote La Prophécie, vision et révélation divine de la prospérité et victoire de Charles VIII (“The Prophecy, Vision and Divine Revelation of the Prosperity and Victory of Charles VIII”), a small, six-leaf work straddling the boundaries between astronomy and astrology, news and propaganda, plebeian naïveté and political manoeuvring. The text, probably contemporaneous with the king’s earliest victories in France and Italy, promises him a dazzling destiny. As was often the case, the printer did not deign to sign a work that was considered minor at the time but is highly sought after today because of its extreme rarity. It is hard to identify which press printed this work, but the combination of Matthias Huss’s characters and Michel Topié’s and Jacques Heremberck’s decorated letters suggests it was probably in Lyon. Nevertheless, it seems wise to attribute the volume to an anonymous "printer of the Praise of victory… of Naples", which Pell (?) identified under the number 7205. He may have been Matthias Huss, the Württemberg-born printer active in Lyon from 1482 to 1500.

Situé à la frontière ténue entre astronomie et astrologie, entre occasionnel et propagande, entre naïveté populaire et manœuvre politique, cet opuscule de six feuillets intitulé La Prophécie, vision et révélation divine de la prospérité et victoire de Charles VIII est signé d’un certain Jean Michel, qui s'intitule lui-même " très pauvre et humble mendiant ", mais que l'on a parfois identifié avec le médecin personnel du roi Charles VIII (1470-1498). Sans doute contemporain des premières victoires du roi de France en Italie, le texte lui promet un destin éclatant. Comme bien souvent, l'imprimeur n’a pas jugé bon de signer une publication considérée alors comme mineure, mais aujourd’hui recherchée car rarissime. L'atelier, certainement lyonnais, d'où est issue cette prophétie est difficile à identifier. S'y mêlent en effet des caractères de Matthias Huss et des lettres ornées de Michel Topié et Jacques Heremberck. Il paraît néanmoins sage de s'en tenir à un anonyme " imprimeur de la Louange de la victoire... de Naples ", identifié par Pell(?) sous le n° 7205, qui est peut-être Matthias Huss, l'éditeur d'origine wurtembourgeoise établi à Lyon et actif dans cette ville entre 1482 et 1500.

europeana:record.dc:title: On the kingdom of Dalmatia and Croatia
De regno Dalmatiae et Croatiae libri sex
europeana:record.dc:creator: Lučić, Ivan, povjesničar
europeana:record.dc:subject: 900 Geography & History
europeana:record.dc:description: This seminal work by Trogir native, Ivan Lučić (Ioannes Lucius, 1604–1679) charts the history of Croatia from ancient times to the 15th century. A lawyer, historian and father of modern historiography, Lučić proved a trail blazer in his use of research data methodology and presentation devices. He used a huge variety of evidence to support his findings and put to use previously less known sources. Lučić used historical and contemporary maps in his research. He endeavoured to accurately reconstruct the sequence of reigns of Croatian rulers as well as five genealogies of prominent Croatian families. Although his views are firmly influenced by the time, his findings still have a valid role in the recording of Croatian history.

De regno Dalmatiae et Croatiae najvažnije je djelo Trogiranina Ivana Lučića (Ioannes Lucius, 1604.–1679.), pravnika i povjesničara, oca moderne hrvatske historiografije. U djelu se opisuje povijest hrvatskih zemalja od prapovijesti do XV. st. Lučić je nadmašio svoje vrijeme po metodologiji istraživanja i prezentiranja podataka: svoje tvrdnje argumentira obilnom građom, a donosi dotada slabo poznate izvore i komentira ih. Služi se povijesnim i suvremenim zemljovidima. U knjizi je pokušao rekonstruirati slijed hrvatskih vladara (kraljeva i banova), donosi i pet rodoslovlja uglednih hrvatskih rodova. Piše skladno, pa iako su mu stajališta pod snažnim utjecajem onoga doba, ni u kasnijim vremenima nije prestajao biti važnim pomoćnikom u rekonstruiranju hrvatske povijesti.
europeana:record.dc:source: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu
europeana:record.dc:rights: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu

europeana:record.dc:title: The Little book of Slavoserbian folk poems
Мала простонародна славено-сербска песнарица
europeana:record.dc:creator: Караџић, Вук Стефановић
europeana:record.dc:subject: 800 - Literature
europeana:record.dc:description: The book represented the basic of Serbian folklore. The first collection of folk poems, collected and edited by Vuk Karadzic.
Књига чини основу српског фолклорног корпуса. Прва Вукова збирка народних песама.

europeana:record.dc:title: Serbian News from the governing city Vienna - 1814
Новине сербске - из царствујушћег града Виене - 1814
europeana:record.dc:creator: b.a.
europeana:record.dc:subject: 900 - History
europeana:record.dc:description: Serbian News from Vienna, the third Serbian newspaper has been edited by Dimitrije Davidovic and Dimitrije Frusic. All famous Serbian authors cooperated in these newspaper, and so did Vuk Karadzic since 1815.
Треће по реду српске новине, уређивали их Димитрије Давидовић и Димитрије Фрушић. Сарађивали су најпознатији српски писци, а од 1815. и Вук Караџић.

europeana:record.dc:title: Serbian folk poems
Народна србска песнарица
europeana:record.dc:creator: Караџић, Вук Стефановић
europeana:record.dc:subject: 800 - Literature
europeana:record.dc:description: The book represents the base of Serbian folklore.
Књига чини основу српског фолклорног корпуса.

europeana:record.dc:title: Meletiy Smotritskiy’s Grammar book
Грамматика
europeana:record.dc:creator: Смотрицкий, Мелетий Герасимович 1578-1633
europeana:record.dc:subject: 400 Language;370 Education;000 Generalities
europeana:record.dc:description: Grammar of Church Slavonic' (1648) is the main work of Melety Smotritsky, reputedly one of the most eminent scholars of the 16th and 17th centuries. His style is remarkable for his new approach to learning and he left a considerable mark on the Philological thought of his time. His 'Grammar', as Lomonosov’s well-turned phrase goes, has become known as the "Gate of scholarship". The text was later considerably edited by proof-readers from the Moscow Pechatny Dvor publishing house. It kept its scientific and practical significance until 1755 when 'Grammar' by Mikhail Lomonosov, was issued.

Мелетий Смотрицкий (Максим Герасимович Смотрицкий) – видный общественный, церковный деятель, педагог и ученый, один из образованнейших людей своего времени; ревностный защитник православия, в конце жизни перешел в греко-католическую церковь. Московское переиздание «Грамматики» Мелетия Смотрицкого появилось анонимно, имя автора не было указано из-за его перехода в конце жизни в униатство. Текст книги был дополнен предисловием, составленным из сочинений Максима Грека о пользе грамматики и философского учения (об изучении грамматики, риторики и философии), а также толкование имен. Книга печаталась с 6 декабря 1647 г. по 2 февраля 1648 г., то есть в течение 13 месяцев. Тираж книги составил 1200 экземпляров. М.В.Ломоносов называл Грамматику Смотрицкого «вратами учености». На протяжении XVII–XVIII вв. «Грамматика» неоднократно переиздавалась в славянских землях, в том числе в Москве в 1648 и 1721 гг. Она сохраняла свое научное и практическое значение вплоть до выхода в свет «Грамматики» М.В. Ломоносова в 1755 г.

europeana:record.dc:title: Kalbos ženklas
europeana:record.dc:creator: Venclova, Tomas
europeana:record.dc:subject: 890 Literatures of other languages;890 Literatures of other languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Tomas Venclova (b.1937) is a prominent contemporary Lithuanian poet, translator, scholar, publicist, professor of Slavic literature at Yale university (USA). His first poetry book "Kalbos ženklas" (The Sign of the Language), published in 1972 is presented in the exhibition. His poetry belongs to the type of discipline poetry.

Tomas Venclova (g. 1937) – žymus šiuolaikinis lietuvių poetas, vertėjas, literatūros tyrinėtojas, publicistas, Jeilio (Yale) universiteto slavų literatūros profesorius. Čia pristatoma pirmoji jo poezijos knyga „Kalbos ženklas“ (1972). Jo poezija priklauso disciplinuotos poezijos tipui. Ji yra ne subjekto būsenų spontaniškas atspindys, o pasaulio išsakymas, chaotiškiems jo pavidalams suteikiant formą, įvardijant nematomus tikrovės ryšius.
europeana:record.dc:source: Martynas Mazvydas National Library of Lithuania

europeana:record.dc:title: Kronika polska litewska, żmódzka y wszystkiej Rusi Kijowskiey, Moskiewskiey, Siewierskiey, Wołynskiej, Podolskiey, Podgorskiey, Podlaskiey
europeana:record.dc:creator: Strijkovskis, Motiejus
europeana:record.dc:subject: 940 General history of Europe
europeana:record.dc:description: Motiejus Strijkovskis' (ca. 1547-1593)"Chronicles" is the first printed history of Lithuania, written in Polish. It covers the period between the alleged Roman arrival in the Baltic lands and the Union of Lublin, which was passed in 1569. All work and individual volumes are dedicated to the Polish-Lithuanian nobles, King Steponas Batoras, Vilnius bishop Jurgis Radvila and Samogitian bishop Merkelis Giedraitis. The work exalts a heroic Lithuanian past and associates its future with Poland.

Pasirinkta knyga – Motiejaus Strijkovskio (apie 1547–1593) „Kronika“ – pirmoji spausdinta Lietuvos istorija, parašyta lenkų kalba ir apimanti laikus nuo tariamo romėnų atvykimo į Baltų žemes iki Liublino unijos (1569) imtinai. Visas kūrinys, atskiri jo tomai bei knygos dedikuojami įvairiems Abiejų Tautų Respublikos didikams – valdovui Steponui Batorui, Vilniaus vyskupui Jurgiui Radvilai ir Žemaičių vyskupui Merkeliui Giedraičiui. Veikale išaukštinta heroiška Lietuvos praeitis, kalbėdamas apie ateitį, ją įsivaizduoja drauge su Lenkija.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: W Krolewcu, drukowano u Gerzego Osterbergera
europeana:record.dc:source: Martynas Mazvydas National Library of Lithuania

europeana:record.dc:title: Griffith Gaunt : or, Jealousy. Vol. 1.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Reade, Charles
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Charles Reade (1814-1884), novelist, playwright and trader in Cremona violins, came from the landed gentry and had been expected to enter the church. He rebelled against his family's conservatiive ambitions and took to writing novels and adapting books for the stage.'The Cloister and the Hearth’ (1861) became his most famous novel, while ‘Griffith Gaunt’ (1866) proved his most controversial with its questioning of contemporary notions of sexual propriety. It's steamy final installment 'All the Year round' even prompted a disclaimer from Dickens. As a promoter of international copyright, he caused consternation when some of his own writings strayed into plagiarism. Much of his income came from stage adaptions of novels that were designed to raise issues that concerned Reade, including prison punishments.

europeana:record.dc:title: Uwagi o śmierci niechybney wszytkim pospolitey
europeana:record.dc:creator: Baka, Juozapas
europeana:record.dc:subject: 890 Literatures of other languages
europeana:record.dc:description: The poetry book of Vilnius University professor of rhetoric, preacher and poet Joseph Bakos (1707-1780) "Uwagi o śmierci niechybney" (Notes on the imminent death) is an example of Late Baroque artistic explorations, first published in Vilnius in 1766. He is free to conduct himself with rhetorical styles and figures of speech. Everything is mixed, connected and alternated with disregard of traditional norms and rules. Relying on classical rules of rhetoric, and at the same time refusing it, he formed his original "parody of the rhetoric".

Vilniaus universiteto retorikos profesoriaus, pamokslininko ir poeto Juozapo Bakos (1707–1780) poezijos tomelis „Uwagi o śmierci niechybney“ („Pastabos apie neišvengiamą mirtį“) – vėlyvojo Baroko meninių ieškojimų pavyzdys (pirmą kartą išleistas Vilniuje 1766 m.). Kūryboje jis laisvai elgiasi su retorikos stiliais, retorinėmis figūromis – viską maišo, jungia, keičia, nepaiso jokių tradicinių normų bei taisyklių. Pasiremdamas klasikinėmis retorikos taisyklėmis ir tuo pačiu metu jų išsižadėdamas, jis sukūrė savitą “retorikos parodiją”.
europeana:record.dc:source: Martynas Mazvydas National Library of Lithuania

europeana:record.dc:title: Second volume of the ingenious gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha
Segunda parte del ingenioso cauallero don Quixote de la Mancha
europeana:record.dc:creator: Cervantes Saavedra, Miguel de (1547-1616)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Literatura
europeana:record.dc:description: Cervantes concluded the Segunda parte del ingenioso caballero don Quijote de la Mancha (Second Volume of the Ingenious Gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha) at the end of 1614, when Avellaneda's continuation had appeared. Before publishing this second part of the Quixote, nine editions of part one had been published, as well as some translations. After its publication separate editions came out, in Spanish as well as in other languages, but it was in 1617 when the first joint edition of both works were published, as a coedition of the booksellers Miguel Gracián, Juan Simón and Rafael Vives from Barcelona. The composition and inner coherence of this work presented differences, and it is worthy of mention that in this edition the divisions present in part one, as well as the burlesque sonnets that appeared at the beginning and the end of the work had all been eliminated.

Cervantes finalizó la Segunda parte del ingenioso caballero don Quijote de la Mancha a finales de 1614, fecha en la que había aparecido la continuación de Avellaneda. Antes de publicarse esta segunda parte del Quijote, la primera había conocido nueve ediciones, además de algunas traducciones. Posteriormente a su publicación salieron a la luz ediciones sueltas, tanto en español como en otras lenguas, pero es en 1617 cuando se publica la primera edición conjunta de ambas partes, como coedición de los libreros barceloneses Miguel Gracián, Juan Simón y Rafael Vives. Como diferencias en cuanto a la composición y coherencia interna de la obra, hay que destacar que en ésta se ha eliminado la división en partes, presente en la primera, además de suprimirse los sonetos burlescos que aparecían al principio y al fin de la obra.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: En Madrid por Iuan de la Cuesta vendese en casa de Francisco de Robles, librero del Rey N.S.

europeana:record.dc:title: Serbian News from the governing city Vienna - 1817
Новине сербске - из царствујушћег града Виене - 1817
europeana:record.dc:creator: b.a.
europeana:record.dc:subject: 900 - History
europeana:record.dc:description: Serbian News from Vienna, the third Serbian newspaper has been edited by Dimitrije Davidovic and Dimitrije Frusic. All famous Serbian authors cooperated in these newspaper, and so did Vuk Karadzic since 1815.
Треће по реду српске новине, уређивали их Димитрије Давидовић и Димитрије Фрушић. Сарађивали су најпознатији српски писци, а од 1815. и Вук Караџић.

europeana:record.dc:title: Iš tylinčios žemės
europeana:record.dc:creator: Bložė, Vytautas
europeana:record.dc:subject: 890 Literatures of other languages;890 Literatures of other languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Vytautas Petras Bložė (b. 09.02.1930) is a poet, an originator of modern Lithuanian literature. In Soviet times, he has been underrated; his two books have been banned. One of his most important books of poetry "Iš tylinčios žemės" (From the Silent Land, 1966) is presented in the exhibition.

Vytautas Petras Bložė (g. 1930 02 09) – poetas, modernizmo lietuvių literatūroje pradininkas. Tarybiniais laikais buvo neįvertintas, uždraustos 2 jo knygos. Čia pristatoma viena svarbiausių jo poezijos knygų – „Iš tylinčios žemės“ (1966).
europeana:record.dc:source: Martynas Mazvydas National Library of Lithuania

europeana:record.dc:title: Treatise on preservation of the wine
Tractatus de vini conservatione
europeana:record.dc:subject: Vin
europeana:record.dc:description: Based on the typefaces and the wear of the characters and certain dropped initials, the Tractatus de vino et ejus proprietate, an anonymous, eight-leaf, technical “treatise on wine and its properties”, can be attributed to Eucharius Silber’s presses in Rome. This volume, which entered the royal library before the French Revolution, is one of three that has come down to us. It attests to an atypical type of printing by a press that thrived from 1480 to the early 16th century before ownership passed to Eucharius’s son, Marcellus: devotional works and brochures, speeches and et sermons relating to the pontifical chancellery, Latin classics, etc. Three other Italian editions, which, like this one, bear no bibliographical address, have been catalogued (IGI 10330-13001, Goff V-298).

Cet opuscule anonyme de huit feuillets peut être attribué aux presses d'Eucharius Silber à Rome d'après l’examen des caractères utilisés. Une fourchette de datation, entre 1495 et 1498, peut se déduire de l'état d'usure des caractères et de certaines lettrines. Le Tractatus de vino et ejus proprietate, traité du vin et de ses propriétés, est un petit manuel technique consacré au produit de la vigne. Cet exemplaire, entré à la Bibliothèque royale avant la Révolution française, est l'un des trois parvenus jusqu'à nous. Il témoigne d'un type d'impression atypique au sein d'un atelier florissant depuis 1480 jusqu'aux premières années du XVIe siècle, avant d’être repris par le fils d’Eucharius, Marcellus Silber : ouvrages et brochures de dévotion, discours et sermons liés à l'activité de la chancellerie pontificale, classiques latins... Trois autres éditions italiennes, tout aussi dépourvues que celle-ci d'adresse bibliographique, sont répertoriées (IGI 10330-13001, Goff V-298)

europeana:record.dc:title: Presentment of the Russian Emperor army dress-coats: 88 coloured images
Изображение мундиров российско-императорскаго войска, состоящих из 88 лиц илюминованных
europeana:record.dc:creator: Люде, Яков фон
europeana:record.dc:subject: 760 Graphic arts, printmaking & prints, postage stamps;940 General history of Europe
europeana:record.dc:description: An illustrated history of military uniforms from the end of the reign of Catherine the Great. The book comprises over 88 gravures of military men's standard Russian Army and Navy attire from high-ranking officers to Cossacks. The paintings and gravures were carried out by Christian G. H. Heisler, a German painter who worked in Russia at the time, with all gravures manually applied with watercolors. There were two sets of gravures sold at the Imperial Cadet corps in St. Petersburg. The first one consisted of 45 gravures illustrating the soldiers’ uniform, the second outlined General Officers’ clothing. Both sets were originally sold for 25 rubles.

Составитель альбома – поручик Финляндского егерского корпуса Яков фон Люде. В книге помещены 88 гравюр с изображениями военных, от генерал-фельдмаршала до казака и башкирца, облаченных в форму, установленную в российской армии и флоте в конце царствования имп. Екатерины II. Рисунки и гравюры выполнены Х.Г.Г. Гейслером (1770-1844), немецким художником, работавшим в России в 1790 – 1798 гг.; гравюры раскрашены вручную акварелью. Судя по объявлениям в «Санктпетербургских ведомостях», гравюры продавались двумя комплектами при Императорском Сухопутном шляхетном кадетском корпусе в Петербурге. Первый комплект состоял из 45 гравюр с изображениями форменной одежды и «арматуры» военнослужащих, второй включал изображения обмундирования высшего офицерского состава. Цена обоих комплектов составляла 25 рублей.

europeana:record.dc:title: Historiae Lituanae pars prior [-posterior]
europeana:record.dc:creator: Kojalavičius-Vijūkas, Albertas
europeana:record.dc:subject: 940 General history of Europe
europeana:record.dc:description: "The History of Lithuania" (2 parts; printed in 1650 and 1669) by Vilnius Jesuit Professor, Jesuit Albertas-Kojalavičius Vijūkas (la. Albertus Wiiuk Koialowicz, 1609-1677) is the most famous work of Lithuanian Baroque historiography. Reffering to the Polish “Chronicle” by sixteenth century historian Maciej Stryjkowski, author wrote the first history of the Lithuanian state distinct from the Slavic world, based on the truth of the country's original development and God's will. "Historiae Lituaniae” is an overview of the events in Lithuanian history from ancient times to the death of Sigismund Augustus in 1572.

Vilniaus jėzuitų profesoriaus jėzuito Alberto Kojalavičiaus-Vijūko „Lietuvos istorija“ (2 t., išspausdinti 1650 ir 1669 metais) – žymiausias Lietuvos Baroko istoriografijos kūrinys, parašytas remiantis XVI a. istoriko Motiejaus Strijkovskio lenkiškai parašyta „Kronika“. „Historiae Lituaniae“ yra pirmoji lietuvių tautos ir lietuvių valstybės istorija, kurioje Lietuva eliminuota iš slavų pasaulio, pateikiama Lietuvos istorijos įvykių apžvalgą nuo seniausių laikų iki Žygimanto Augusto mirties (1572).
europeana:record.dc:publisher: Gdańsk, Jerzy Förster; Antwerpen, Jacob van Meurs
europeana:record.dc:source: Martynas Mazvydas National Library of Lithuania

Треће по реду српске новине, уређивали их Димитрије Давидовић и Димитрије Фрушић. Сарађивали су најпознатији српски писци, а од 1815. и Вук Караџић.

Мезимац
europeana:record.dc:creator: Обрадовић, Доситеј
europeana:record.dc:subject: 800 - Literature

Kњига просветитељских огледа која показује повезаност са савременим темама и проблемима српске и европске културе (језика, науке, културе, друштва).
europeana:record.dc:publisher: Будим, Из Печатне Кралев. Мађар. Свеучилишта

europeana:record.dc:title: Balta drobulė
europeana:record.dc:creator: Škėma, Antanas
europeana:record.dc:subject: 890 Literatures of other languages;890 Literatures of other languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Antanas Škėma (1910-1961)was a prominent writer of Lithuanian emigration, playwright and dramatist, representative of modernism. In his best known novel "Balta drobulė" (The White Shroud) Škėma discusses the soul of the artist, his talent and squalor, the poet’s nature and also issues of responsibility in the post-war world, especially as these relate to existential anxieties within the context of a world perceived as absurd.

Antanas Škėma (1910-1961) - lietuvių išeivijos rašytojas, prozininkas ir dramaturgas, modernizmo atstovas. Čia pristatomas reikšmingiausias jo kūrinys – romanas „Balta drobulė“. Keliaaukštė romano struktūra, laiko planų žaismė lemia teksto daugiareikšmiškumą. Autorius apmąsto menininko likimą pokariniame pasaulyje, atskleidžia kūrybinio proceso dinamiką, svarsto poeto prigimties ir atsakomybės klausimą, siedamas jį su egzistenciniu istorijos ir pasaulio beprasmybės idėjų kontekstu.
europeana:record.dc:source: Martynas Mazvydas National Library of Lithuania

Народне српске приповијетке

europeana:record.dc:subject: 800 - Literature

Књига чини основу српског фолклорног корпуса.

europeana:record.dc:title: The works of Boscan and some by Garcilasso de la Vega in four books
Las obras de Boscan y algunas de Garcilasso de la Vega repartidas en quatro libros
europeana:record.dc:creator: Garcilaso de la Vega (1501-1536)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Literatura
europeana:record.dc:description: The editorial history of their works and the introduction of Italian Renaissance poetry into Spain have united Boscán and Garcilaso de la Vega in the history of literature. Boscán hired the bookseller Joan Bages to print his poems, which would come from the press of Carles Amoros in 1543, in a work characterised by the variety of fonts used. It is believed that this edicio princeps reproduces an original copy prepared by Boscán himself and selected among his production. IV Libro (Book IV), also in edicio princeps, contains the odes, elegies and sonnets of Garcilaso, whose manuscripts had passed to his good friend Boscán after his death, as explained in the forward addressed to the readers. After publishing nineteen joint editions, in 1569 Mathias Gast published the work of Garcilaso separately for the first time.

La historia editorial de sus obras y la introducción de la poesía renacentista italiana en España han unido a Boscán y a Garcilaso de la Vega en la historia de la literatura. Boscán, contrató con el librero Joan Bages la impresión de sus poesías, que saldrían en 1543 de las prensas de Carles Amoros, con un trabajo caracterizado por la variedad de tipos empleados. Se cree que esta edición príncipe reproduce un original de imprenta preparado por el propio Boscán y seleccionado entre su producción. En el IV Libro aparecen, también en edición princeps, las odas, elegías y sonetos de Garcilaso, cuyos manuscritos habían pasado a su muerte a manos de su buen amigo Boscán, como se explica en una nota preliminar dirigida a los lectores. Tras diecinueve ediciones publicándose en conjunto, en 1569 Mathias Gast editó por primera vez las obras de Garcilaso por separado.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: En Barcelona en la officina de Garles [sic] Amoros

europeana:record.dc:title: Anafielas
europeana:record.dc:creator: Kraszewski, Józef Ignacy
europeana:record.dc:subject: 890 Literatures of other languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Juzefas Ignacas Kraševskis (pl. Józef Ignacy Kraszewski, 1812-1887) was alumni of Vilnius University, where he studied literature. He was one of the world's most prolific writers of all times and created about 600 volumes of various works, included 223 novels. His historical novels are the most valuable (94 novels totally). Kraševskis was interested in the history of Lithuania, Lithuanian culture and folklore, and wrote poems on Lithuanian history. Poetic trilogy “Anafielas” (1840-1845) was particularly interesting for Lithuanians, especially its first part “Witolorauda” (The Plaint of Vitol). This is the first attempt of Lithuanian mythological epos. In Polish literature, this work was forgotten soon, however, translated into Lithuanian, it remained popular.

Juzefas Ignacas Kraševskis (1812–1887) – Vilniaus universiteto auklėtinis, čia studijavęs literatūrą. Jis buvo vienas produktyviausių pasaulio rašytojų, kurio raštus sudaro apie 600 tomų (iš jų 223 romanai). Labiausiai vertinami jo istoriniai romanai, kurių yra 94. Kraševskis domėjosi Lietuvos istorija, lietuvių kultūra ir tautosaka, rašė eiles Lietuvos istorijos temomis. Ypatingo lietuvių dėmesio susilaukė čia pristatoma Kraševskio poetinė trilogija Anafielas (1840-1845), ypač jos pirmoji dalis Witolorauda (Vitolio rauda) -lietuviško mitologinio epo bandymas. Lenkų literatūroje tas veikalas buvo netrukus užmirštas, tačiau išverstas į lietuvių kalbą liko plačiai skaitomas ir mėgstamas.
europeana:record.dc:source: Martynas Mazvydas National Library of Lithuania

Политическая переписка императрицы Екатерины II. ч.1 1762 и 1763 г.
europeana:record.dc:subject: 320 Political science;920 Biography, genealogy, insignia;940 General history of Europe

Часть 1-ая (годы с 1762 по 1763). Том издан бароном Ф.А.Бюлером, при содействии магистра В.А.Уляницкаго

europeana:record.dc:title: The Novel without the Novel
Роман без романа
europeana:record.dc:creator: Поповић, Јован Стерија
europeana:record.dc:subject: 800 - Literature
europeana:record.dc:description: The novel represents the showdown with the romanticism and adventure literature. The most significant parody and satiric novel.
Роман представља обрачун са романтичарском и авантуристичком књижевношћу. Најзначајнији пародично-сатирични роман.

europeana:record.dc:title: Letters
Писма
europeana:record.dc:creator: Обрадовић, Доситеј
europeana:record.dc:subject: 800 - Literature
europeana:record.dc:description: This book is a first collection of Dositej's private letters, the valuable document about Dositej's life, but also about Serbian literature and cultural, social and historical environment in which Dositej worked and created.
Књига је прва збирка Доситејевих приватних писама, вредан документ о животу Доситејевом, али и о српској књижевности и културним и друштвено-историјским приликама у којима је Доситеј стварао.

europeana:record.dc:title: Griffith Gaunt : or, Jealousy. Vol. 2.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Reade, Charles
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Charles Reade (1814-1884), novelist, playwright and trader in Cremona violins, came from the landed gentry and had been expected to enter the church. He rebelled against his family's conservatiive ambitions and took to writing novels and adapting books for the stage.'The Cloister and the Hearth’ (1861) became his most famous novel, while ‘Griffith Gaunt’ (1866) proved his most controversial with its questioning of contemporary notions of sexual propriety. It's steamy final installment 'All the Year round' even prompted a disclaimer from Dickens. As a promoter of international copyright, he caused consternation when some of his own writings strayed into plagiarism. Much of his income came from stage adaptions of novels that were designed to raise issues that concerned Reade, including prison punishments.

europeana:record.dc:title: The collection or chronicles of the histories of the kingdoms of Austrasia or Eastern France, now called Lorrain, Jerusalem, Sicily and the duchy of Bar
Le recueil ou croniques des hystoires des royaulmes d'Austrasie ou France orientale dite à présent Lorrayne, de Hierusalem, de Cicile, et de la duché de Bar
europeana:record.dc:creator: Champier, Symphorien (1472?-1539)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Gravure sur bois -- France
europeana:record.dc:description: Lyon physician Symphorien Champier (1472?-1539) left an abundant body of work on not only medicine but also history, theology and philosophy. He took an active part in his city’s affairs before becoming the personal physician of Duke Antoine of Lorraine (1489-1544) in 1509-1510 and following him to Italy. Champier printed this “collection or chronicles of the histories of the kingdoms of Austrasia” in Lyon. It came out at the Lyon bookseller’s Vincent de Portonariis and the Nancy address. The traditional design, with engravings of the author giving his book to the duke at the head of his knights and scenes from tales of chivalry, helped establish the legend that the dukes of Lorraine descended from Pippin the Short (715?-768), king of the Franks, and Emperor Charlemagne (742-814) and are related to Godefroy de Bouillon (Godefroy IV, duke of Lower Lorraine, 1060-1100) as well as the kings of Jerusalem. The dukes of Guise later took up that theme as the basis of their claims to the French throne

Le médecin lyonnais Symphorien Champier (1472?-1539) laissa une œuvre abondante qui touchait aussi bien à la médecine et à l’histoire qu’à la théologie et à la philosophie. Sa vie durant, il participa activement aux affaires de sa ville qu’il quitta cependant pour devenir, en 1509-1510, le médecin personnel du duc Antoine de Lorraine (1489-1544) qu’il suivit en Italie. Il publia alors ce Recueil ou chroniques des histoires des royaumes d’Austrasie. Imprimé à Lyon, l’ouvrage parut à la fois chez le libraire lyonnais Vincent de Portonariis et à l’adresse de Nancy. D’une conception traditionnelle, avec ses gravures représentant l’auteur offrant son livre au duc ou le duc à la tête de ses chevaliers, et ses scènes tirées de romans de chevalerie, il contribua à établir la légende qui fait descendre les ducs de Lorraine du roi des Francs Pépin le Bref (715?-768) et de l'empereur Charlemagne (742-814) et les apparente à Godefroy de Bouillon (Godefroy IV, duc de basse-Lorraine, 1060-1100) et aux rois de Jérusalem, thème qui sera repris ultérieurement pour soutenir les prétentions des Guise à la couronne de France.

europeana:record.dc:title: The order of the coronation of the very christian king our sire Francis of Valois, first of that name
Lordre du Sacre et couronnement du Roy treschrestien notre sire Francoys de valoys, premier de ce nom
europeana:record.dc:subject: Rois et souverains -- France
europeana:record.dc:description: The earliest newspapers, which appeared in the late 14th century, reported on Charles VIII’s victories in Italy but soon broadened their scope to include the royal family’s important events, births, weddings and coronations, contributing to the king’s image. Many copies of the brochures were printed immediately after the events occurred but they are very rare today. They are always short booklets in Gothic characters, without the printer’s name, and often illustrated by a woodcut on the title page that was usually borrowed from another work. It is unusual to find a copy like this one, which features an illustration printed specifically for the occasion: the archbishop of Reims crowning Francis I surrounded by the peers of France. The woodcut was reused in several chivalry romances printed in Paris in the following years.

Les premiers bulletins d’information, apparus dans les dernières années du XVe siècle, rapportaient les victoires de Charles VIII en Italie. Leur sujet s’élargit rapidement aux faits marquants de la vie des princes, les naissances, les mariages, les sacres et les entrées, contribuant ainsi à la propagande royale et à l’affirmation de l’image du souverain. Ces brochures, imprimées aussitôt après l’événement, firent l’objet de multiples éditions, toutes fort rares aujourd’hui. Elles se présentent toujours sous la forme de courts livrets, en caractères gothiques, sans nom d’imprimeur, et sont souvent illustrées d’une gravure sur bois au titre, généralement empruntée à d’autres ouvrages. Il est inhabituel de trouver, comme ici, une illustration gravée spécialement pour la circonstance et parfaitement adaptée au sujet, puisqu’elle représente l’instant même où l’archevêque de Reims couronne François Ier entouré des pairs de France. Ce bois sera réutilisé dans plusieurs romans de chevalerie imprimés à Paris dans les années suivantes.

europeana:record.dc:title: Greek alphabet
Alphabetum graecum
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religion -- Étude et enseignement
europeana:record.dc:description: Bookseller Robert Estienne showed an interest in the teaching of ancient languages as soon as he opened up his own shop, and well before becoming the king’s printer of Hebrew in 1539 and Greek in 1540. In the 1528 fascicule on display here, he used a simple method to present the Greek and Hebrew alphabets in a few pages: the characters are shown with their corresponding Latin letters and, for the Greek, a list of abbreviations with their development. The difficulty in learning how to read Greek came from the many ligatures and contractions, copied from manuscripts, that Paris typographers used. The text of the Modus orandi, drawn from the Gospel of Saint Matthew, and of the Decalogue, provides Greek and Hebrew reading exercises. This elementary primer is a veritable manifesto of the humanist programme Robert Estienne espoused. Like the other great printer-booksellers of his day, he always produced small, immediately profitable schoolbooks at the same time as major works that were more of a long-term investment

À peine installé à son compte, bien avant d’être nommé Imprimeur du roi pour l’hébreu en 1539 et pour le grec en 1540, le libraire Robert Estienne avait manifesté son intérêt pour la pédagogie des langues anciennes. En 1528, dans le fascicule montré ici, il avait ainsi présenté en quelques pages les alphabets hébreu et grec, selon une méthode simple : les alphabets sont donnés avec leur correspondance latine et complétés pour le grec de la liste des abréviations avec leur développement. La réelle difficulté dans l’apprentissage de la lecture du grec venait en effet des nombreuses ligatures et contractions, imitées des manuscrits, qu’utilisaient les typographes parisiens. Le texte du Modus orandi, tiré de l’Évangile de saint Mathieu, et celui du Décalogue, fournissent des exercices de lecture grecque et hébraïque. Ce manuel élémentaire constitue un véritable manifeste du programme humaniste auquel s’adonnera Robert Estienne. Comme les autres grands libraires-imprimeurs de son temps, il maintiendra toujours une production de petits ouvrages scolaires à profit immédiat à côté de grandes entreprises éditoriales au gain plus lointain.

europeana:record.dc:title: How to translate one language into another well
La manière de bien traduire d'une langue en aultre
europeana:record.dc:creator: Dolet, Étienne (1509?-1546)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Français (langue) -- Moyen français
europeana:record.dc:description: At first, humanist, poet and philologist Étienne Dolet set out to continue the beautiful classical Latin tradition represented by Cicero. Then, like his role model, who had imitated the Greeks in his own language, Dolet became a proponent of French. As soon as he set up a press in Lyon in 1538 he started writing a huge work, L’Orateur François (“The French Orator”), which was supposed to include nine treatises on grammar, spelling, phonetics, etymology, translation, rhetoric and poetics. The copy of La Maniere de bien traduire (“The Manner of Translating Well”) on display here, which is only a fragment, came out in 1540. In it Dolet suggested spelling changes (use of the apostrophe and "és" instead of "ez" in the plural) and ideas he had implemented in his translations of Cicero and Plato into French. His hard life – he was executed for heresy in August 1546 – prevented him from finishing the work, but other French language reformers, Joachim Du Bellay foremost among them, were familiar with his ideas

Humaniste, poète et philologue, Étienne Dolet s’attacha d’abord à soutenir la belle latinité classique représentée par Cicéron. Par la suite, à l’instar de son modèle, qui avait imité les Grecs dans sa langue, Dolet va se faire le défenseur du français. À peine installé comme imprimeur à Lyon en 1538, il s’engagea dans un vaste ouvrage, L’Orateur françois, qui devait comprendre neuf traités couvrant la grammaire, l’orthographe, la phonétique, l’étymologie, la traduction, la rhétorique et la poétique. Seul un fragment, cette Maniere de bien traduire présentée ici, parut en 1540. Dolet y proposait des évolutions orthographiques (usage de l’apostrophe, pluriel en " és " et pas " ez ") et des principes de traduction qu’il appliqua lui-même dans sa mise en français de textes de Cicéron et de Platon. Son existence difficile, jusqu’à son exécution pour hérésie en août 1546, ne lui permit pas d’achever l’œuvre projetée, mais ses idées ne furent pas méconnues des autres réformateurs de la langue française, et en premier lieu de Joachim Du Bellay.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Catalogue of books censured by the Paris theology faculty
Le Catalogue des livres censurez par la faculté de Théologie de Paris.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Université de Paris (1215-1793). Faculté de théologie
europeana:record.dc:subject: Censure (droit canonique)
europeana:record.dc:description: In 1517 the universities of Louvain, Cologne and Paris started banning the writings of German theologian Martin Luther (1483-1546) and other reformers but did not publish the condemnations. The Paris theology faculty was the first to draft a handwritten list of the forbidden books, which Jean André, a bookseller specialising in royal acts and Catholic propaganda, published in August 1544. It was republished several times in Paris, and others appeared in Louvain, Venice, Rome, Antwerp, etc. Then the Roman Index became the law of the land throughout Catholic Europe. The 230 books on the 1544 Paris Index are arranged in alphabetical order of the authors or, if they were unknown, titles. They include Pantagruel and Gargantua by François Rabelais (1494?-1553), who apparently was at first banned for obscenity rather than heresy. Its first owner, Martin Bésard, a Swiss proofreader in Paris, abundantly annotated the Bibliothèque Nationale de France copy.

À partir de 1517, les universités de Louvain, de Cologne et de Paris interdisent les écrits du théologien allemand Martin Luther (1483-1546), puis des autres réformateurs, mais ne publient pas ces condamnations. La faculté de théologie de Paris est la première à établir une liste manuscrite des livres censurés, qui est publiée en août 1544 chez Jean André, un libraire spécialisé dans les actes royaux et la propagande catholique. Cet Index est réédité plusieurs fois à Paris, tandis que d'autres paraissent à Louvain, Venise, Rome, Anvers, etc. L'Index romain s'impose ensuite à l'Europe catholique. Les deux cent trente titres de l'Index parisien de 1544 sont organisés par ordre alphabétique d'auteurs ou de titres pour les ouvrages dont les auteurs sont inconnus. On y trouve Pantagruel et Gargantua de François Rabelais (1494?-1553), condamnés semble-t-il d’abord pour obscénité et non pour hérésie. L’exemplaire de la Bibliothèque nationale de France présente la particularité d'avoir été abondamment annoté par son premier possesseur, Martin Bésard, un Suisse correcteur d'imprimerie à Paris.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Voices of Spring
Pavasario balsai
europeana:record.dc:creator: Maironis
europeana:record.dc:subject: 890 Literatures of other languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Jonas Mačiulis-Maironis (1862-1932) was a founder of new Lithuanian poetry, the greatest poet of the period of Lithuanian press ban. He had expressed the national aims of that time and was called the singer of the national renaissance. His poetry had influenced other writers so much that it was called Maironis poetry school in literature. The collection of poems "Voices of Spring" had reflected the past, everyday life and heroism of fights for freedom, emotions of love to the homeland, sensations of the nature's beauty, pride in the native language. It had followed and stylised the folk art. Maironis had expressed important ideas of national renaissance by using impressive poetic images and sensitive poetical means, he had awakened the enthusiasm to fight and hope of rebirth, he had raised the level of Lithuanian poetry to the highest standards of perfection. The creative work of Maironis is a clear division between the old and new Lithuanian poetry.

Jonas Mačiulis-Maironis (1862–1932) – naujosios lietuvių poezijos pradininkas, spaudos draudžiamojo laikotarpio didžiausias poetas, savo poezijoje išreiškęs to meto tautinius siekimus, dėl to vadinamas tautinio atgimimo dainiumi. Savo poezijos įtaka kitiems rašytojams sukūrė lietuvių literatūroje vadinamąją maironinę mokyklą. Maironio „Pavasario balsuose“ atsispindi praeities buitis ir laisvės kovų heroika, tėvynės meilės jausmai, gamtos grožio pajautimas, aukštinama gimtoji kalba, sekama bei stilizuojama liaudies kūryba. Poetas įtaigiais poezijos vaizdais ir jautriomis emocinėmis priemonėmis išreiškė tautinio atgimimo laikotarpio svarbiąsias idėjas, žadino kovos entuziazmą ir prisikėlimo viltį, lietuvių poezijos lygį iškėlė į aukšto tobulumo laipsnį. Jo kūryba – takoskyra tarp senosios ir naujosios lietuvių poezijos.
europeana:record.dc:source: Martynas Mazvydas National Library of Lithuania

europeana:record.dc:title: Architecture, or Art de of building well by Marcus Vitruvius Pollio
Architecture, ou Art de bien bastir de Marc Vitruve Pollion
europeana:record.dc:creator: Vitruve (1er siècle av. J.-C.)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Art -- 16e siècle
europeana:record.dc:description: This book, the first full-length French edition of The Ten Books on Architecture by Roman architect Marcus Vitruvius Pollio, helped spark France’s architectural renewal that began with Philibert Delorme (1510?-1570) and Pierre Lescot in the mid-16th century. The triumph of Classicism made it necessary to have access to this seminal text, the only ancient architecture treatise to have survived. The humanist Jean Martin (?-1553?), who called himself a "student of architecture", printed this edition, remarkable for its illustrations, most of which were drawn by Jean Goujon (1510?-1567?), then the architect of Anne, Duke de Montmorency (1493-1567) in Écouen. The translator’s preface and illustrator’s postscript provide keys to an approach both men shared: using words and pictures to help readers understand an obscure, often abstract text whose images had been amputated in Antiquity in order to offer architects, and not learned men, the theoretical basics they lacked. This translation largely contributed to introducing a new technical vocabulary in French combining adaptations from Vitruvius’s Latin lexicon with traditional terms used by masons and builders that Jean Martin successfully consulted. The index particularly important in that regard.

Cette première édition intégrale en français de l’œuvre de l'architecte romain Vitruve, Architecture ou Art de bien bâtir de Marc Vitruve Pollion s’inscrit dans le renouveau architectural français qui voit débuter au milieu du XVIe siècle Philibert Delorme (1510?-1570) et Pierre Lescot. Le triomphe d’un style à l’antique rendait nécessaire l’accès à ce texte fondateur, le seul traité d’architecture classique qui nous soit parvenu. On doit cette édition à l’humaniste Jean Martin (15..-1553?) qui se qualifiait lui-même de " studieux d’architecture ". L’ouvrage est remarquable pour son illustration dont l’essentiel a été dessiné par Jean Goujon (1510?-1567?), alors architecte du connétable Anne, duc de Montmorency (1493-1567) à Écouen. La préface du traducteur et la postface de l’illustrateur donnent la clé d’une démarche commune : éclaircir sur le plan linguistique et graphique un texte souvent abstrait et obscur, amputé depuis l’Antiquité de ses images, pour offrir aux praticiens --- et non aux lettrés --- la base théorique qui leur manquait. Cette traduction a grandement contribué à introduire en français un nouveau vocabulaire technique, mêlant des adaptations du lexique vitruviano-italien aux termes traditionnels des maçons et maîtres d’ouvrage que Jean Martin dit avoir consultés avec profit. L’index qui clôture ce volume est à cet égard particulièrement important.

europeana:record.dc:title: The order of the new and joyous entrance that the very excellent, very powerful and very high Prince, the very christian King Henry the second made in his good city of Paris… the sixteenth day of June M. D. XLIX

C'est l'ordre qui a este tenu a la nouvelle et ioyeuse entrée, que treshault, tresexcellent, et trespuissant Prince, le Roy treschrestien Henry deuzieme de ce nom a faicte en sa bonne ville et cite de Paris,... le seizieme iour de Iuin M. D. XLIX
europeana:record.dc:subject: Gravure sur bois -- France
europeana:record.dc:description: After his 1547 coronation in Reims, Henry II (1519-1559), following custom, made nearly 30 solemn entrances into the kingdom’s towns, including a superb one in Lyon in 1548. The ceremonies were accompanied by extravagant fêtes where sumptuous gifts were lavished on the king, who confirmed the towns’ privileges in return. The Paris entrance, postponed for political reasons, took place on 16 June 1549 after the queen’s coronation in Saint-Denis. Contemporary accounts describe it as having been of unequalled splendour and originality. Jean Martin, a translator of Latin and Italian books who travelled in young humanist circles, was called upon to organise the celebrations. He asked poet Thomas Sébillet and artists Jean Cousin, Charles Dorigny and Jean Goujon to design and carry out a complex programme dominated by architectural elements. The booklet, which modified and embellished the décors’ and inscriptions’ detail, contributed to the repercussions of the ceremony, which, more than any other that had ever come before it, asserted the king’s almighty power and fostered the development of a learned culture.

Après son sacre à Reims en 1547, Henri II (1519-1559) effectua, selon la coutume, près de trente entrées solennelles dans les principales villes du royaume, dont une superbe entrée à Lyon en 1548. Ces cérémonies étaient l’occasion de fêtes somptueuses où de riches présents étaient offerts au roi, qui, de son côté, confirmait les privilèges des villes. L’entrée à Paris, d’abord différée pour des motifs politiques, eut enfin lieu le 16 juin 1549, à la suite du couronnement de la reine à Saint-Denis. À en croire les témoignages contemporains, elle fut d’une richesse et d’une originalité inégalées. L’organisation en fut confiée à Jean Martin, un traducteur d’œuvres latines et italiennes qui fréquentait le milieu des jeunes humanistes. Il fit appel au poète Thomas Sébillet et aux artistes Jean Cousin, Charles Dorigny et Jean Goujon pour concevoir et réaliser un programme complexe, que dominaient les éléments architecturaux. Le livret, qui modifiait et enjolivait le détail des décors et des inscriptions, contribua au retentissement de cette cérémonie, qui, plus que les entrées précédentes, affirma la toute-puissance royale et participa à l’élaboration d’une culture savante.

europeana:record.dc:title: Der arme Spielmann
europeana:record.dc:creator: Grillparzer, Franz
europeana:record.dc:subject: 830 Literatures of Germanic languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Germany is contributing digitised versions of well-known literary works by German authors from different centuries to "Reading Europe". The printed editions of these titles, taken from the stocks of the German National Library, were digitised. The brief of the library is to collect Germany's published cultural and scientific heritage since 1913, to preserve it for posterity and to make it accessible for use. The German National Library therefore documents the intellectual and literary output of the German-speaking countries. Subject librarians from the library made the selections for "Reading Europe", choosing exclusively volumes which are no longer subject to copyright.

Deutschlands Beitrag zu "Reading Europe" sind die Digitalisate von bekannten literarischen Werken deutscher Autoren aus allen Jahrhunderten. Digitalisiert wurden die Druckausgaben dieser Titel aus dem Bestand der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek, die das kulturelle und wissenschaftliche Erbe Deutschlands in seiner ab 1913 veröffentlichten Form sammelt, es für immer bewahrt und für die Nutzung zugänglich macht. Die Deutsche Nationalbibliothek dokumentiert damit das geistige und literarische Schaffen im deutschen Sprachraum. Die Auswahl für "Reading Europe" trafen Fachreferentinnen und Fachreferenten der Bibliothek, ausgewählt wurden ausschließlich Bände, die nicht mehr dem Urheberschutz unterliegen.

europeana:record.dc:title: Leyer und Schwerdt
europeana:record.dc:creator: Körner, Theodor ; Kircheisen, Friedrich M. [Hrsg.]
europeana:record.dc:subject: 830 Literatures of Germanic languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Germany is contributing digitised versions of well-known literary works by German authors from different centuries to "Reading Europe". The printed editions of these titles, taken from the stocks of the German National Library, were digitised. The brief of the library is to collect Germany's published cultural and scientific heritage since 1913, to preserve it for posterity and to make it accessible for use. The German National Library therefore documents the intellectual and literary output of the German-speaking countries. Subject librarians from the library made the selections for "Reading Europe", choosing exclusively volumes which are no longer subject to copyright.

Deutschlands Beitrag zu "Reading Europe" sind die Digitalisate von bekannten literarischen Werken deutscher Autoren aus allen Jahrhunderten. Digitalisiert wurden die Druckausgaben dieser Titel aus dem Bestand der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek, die das kulturelle und wissenschaftliche Erbe Deutschlands in seiner ab 1913 veröffentlichten Form sammelt, es für immer bewahrt und für die Nutzung zugänglich macht. Die Deutsche Nationalbibliothek dokumentiert damit das geistige und literarische Schaffen im deutschen Sprachraum. Die Auswahl für "Reading Europe" trafen Fachreferentinnen und Fachreferenten der Bibliothek, ausgewählt wurden ausschließlich Bände, die nicht mehr dem Urheberschutz unterliegen.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Spaniards painted by themselves
Los españoles pintados por si mismos
europeana:record.dc:subject: Costumbrismo
europeana:record.dc:description: Due to the better quills of the time, this work imitates the French Les français peints par eux mêmes (The French Drawn by Themselves). Ignacio Boix is one of the most representative names in book publishing in the mid-19th century in Madrid, and this publication is one of his most important. It reflects the romantic postulates that extolled the manifestation of personality and sought the roots of national sentiment. It also reflects the resurgence of wood engraving (woodcut or counterfibre xilography) which, performed with ability by the engravers of the time, made it possible to achieve effects on wood similar to those achieved on paper with a pencil or quill. The text has great literary value; it contains an introduction and ninety-nine short articles by contemporary writers, two of them by Mesonero Romanos, signed under the pen name El Curioso Parlante (the Inquisitive Speaker).

Esta obra, debida a las mejores plumas de la época, imita a la francesa Les français peints par eux mêmes. Ignacio Boix es uno de los nombres más representativos en la edición de libros en Madrid a mediados del siglo XIX, y esta publicación, una de las más importantes. Refleja los postulados románticos que exaltaban la manifestación de la personalidad y buscaban las raíces del sentimiento nacional. También refleja el resurgimiento del grabado en madera (xilografías a la testa o a contrafibra) que, trabajado con la habilidad de los grabadores de esta época, permite obtener sobre la madera efectos análogos a los obtenidos con el lápiz o la pluma sobre el papel. El texto es de gran valor literario; contiene una introducción y noventa y nueve artículos cortos de escritores contemporáneos, dos de ellos de Mesonero Romanos, firmados con el seudónimo de El Curioso Parlante.

europeana:record.dc:title: Das Kajütenbuch
europeana:record.dc:creator: Sealsfield, Charles
europeana:record.dc:subject: 830 Literatures of Germanic languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Germany is contributing digitised versions of well-known literary works by German authors from different centuries to "Reading Europe". The printed editions of these titles, taken from the stocks of the German National Library, were digitised. The brief of the library is to collect Germany's published cultural and scientific heritage since 1913, to preserve it for posterity and to make it accessible for use. The German National Library therefore documents the intellectual and literary output of the German-speaking countries. Subject librarians from the library made the selections for "Reading Europe", choosing exclusively volumes which are no longer subject to copyright.

Deutschlands Beitrag zu "Reading Europe" sind die Digitalisate von bekannten literarischen Werken deutscher Autoren aus allen Jahrhunderten. Digitalisiert wurden die Druckausgaben dieser Titel aus dem Bestand der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek, die das kulturelle und wissenschaftliche Erbe Deutschlands in seiner ab 1913 veröffentlichten Form sammelt, es für immer bewahrt und für die Nutzung zugänglich macht. Die Deutsche Nationalbibliothek dokumentiert damit das geistige und literarische Schaffen im deutschen Sprachraum. Die Auswahl für "Reading Europe" trafen Fachreferentinnen und Fachreferenten der Bibliothek, ausgewählt wurden ausschließlich Bände, die nicht mehr dem Urheberschutz unterliegen.

europeana:record.dc:title: The beautiful figures and strange acts of the League …
Les belles Figures et Drolleries de la Ligue …
europeana:record.dc:creator: L'Estoile, Pierre de (1546-1611)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Imagerie populaire -- 16e siècle
europeana:record.dc:description: Paris jurist Pierre de L’Estoile (1546-1611) stayed in the capital during the late 16th unrest. Attached to the legitimate monarchy, a steadfast Catholic but a friend of many Reformationists, he wrote down all the news he could gather and collected writings in circulation – satirical placards, pamphlets, poems and songs – amassing over 300 pieces on the Catholic League sold in the streets of Paris. The collection he called Les belles figures et drolleries de la Ligue is all that has survived. The pieces, some annotated by L’Estoile, are glued to each other back to back and sometimes overlap in roughly chronological order. They are often unique examples of the living character and narrative qualities of the great woodcuts Paris printmakers made to record the civil wars’ main events. Historians made abundant use of the collection, which helped to create the League’s image in the popular imagination.

Le juriste parisien Pierre de L’Estoile (1546-1611) ne quitta pas la capitale pendant les troubles de la fin du XVIe siècle. Attaché à la monarchie légitime, catholique sincère mais lié d’amitié avec des réformés, il traversa les événements en notant toutes les nouvelles qu’il pouvait recueillir et en ramassant les écrits qui circulaient : placards satiriques, pamphlets, poèmes et chansons. Il réunit plus de trois cents pièces sur la Ligue, vendues dans les rues de Paris. Seul a subsisté le recueil qu’il appella Les belles figures et drolleries de la Ligue. Les pièces, parfois annotées par L’Estoile, y sont collées recto verso et même se chevauchent, dans un ordre à peu près chronologique. Elles offrent des exemples souvent uniques du caractère vivant et des qualités narratives des grandes images gravées sur bois par les imagiers parisiens qui retracent ainsi les principales journées des guerres civiles. Abondamment utilisé par les historiens, ce recueil contribua à fixer l’imagerie de la Ligue.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Bondman : A new saga. Vol. 3 : The book of Red Jason
europeana:record.dc:creator: Caine, Thomas Henry Hall
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Author Hall Caine (1853-1931) became one Victorian England's wealthiest novelists, despite a humble background as the son of a smith and seamstress. ‘The Deemster’ (1887) was his first success and was adapted for the stage, which proved an added source of income. His novel ‘The Christian’ (1897) is reputed to be the first British novel to sell a million copies. Caine's 1890 work ‘The Bondman’ is a complex revenge/romance set in the late 18th century Isle of Man and in Iceland. Its success launched the firm of Heinemann, pioneers in publishing advertising techniques.

europeana:record.dc:title: Epistle sent to the Tiger of France
Epistre envoiée au Tigre de la France
europeana:record.dc:creator: Hotman, François (1524-1590)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Protestants -- France -- 1517-1787
europeana:record.dc:description: This anonymous pamphlet, which bears neither the date nor the place of its printing, appeared shortly after the Amboise plot (March 1560), when the Reformers were trying to justify their armed attempt to remove young King Francis II (1544-1560) from the Guise family’s influence. It neither claimed to explain their position nor appealed to royal justice, but attacked Charles de Lorraine, Cardinal de Guise (1525-1574), by using the metaphor of the tiger, which bestiaries considered the most ferocious animal, and the viper, which introduced the idea of malice, a charge often levelled against the cardinal. His violence left Charles de Lorraine "flabbergasted", according to the lord of Brantôme (1540?-1614). In the 19th century this document was attributed to François Hotman (1524-1590), a Paris jurist living in Strasbourg; since then, the typeface used by a printer from the town, Christian Mylius, has been identified. The suspicions of the Duke de Guise, who in 1561 complained that the accusations published against his family in Strasbourg were "slanderous libels", were therefore well founded.

Sans nom d'auteur, sans lieu ni date d'impression, ce pamphlet appelé d'après l'apostrophe initiale le Tigre, parut peu après la conjuration d'Amboise (mars 1560), alors que les réformés cherchaient à justifier leur tentative armée pour soustraire le jeune roi François II (1544-1560) à l'influence des Guise. Il ne prétend pas expliquer leur position ni en appeler à la justice royale, mais attaque Charles de Lorraine, cardinal de Guise (1525-1574) en utilisant la double métaphore du tigre, considéré par les bestiaires comme le plus féroce des animaux, et de la vipère qui introduit l'idée de malice, accusation souvent portée contre le cardinal. Sa violence laissa Charles de Lorraine " estomaqué " selon le mot du seigneur de Brantôme (1540?-1614). Au XIXe siècle, il fut attribué à François Hotman (1524-1590), un juriste parisien installé à Strasbourg ; depuis on y a reconnu le matériel typographique d'un imprimeur de la ville, Christian Mylius ; les soupçons du duc de Guise, qui se plaignit en 1561 des " libelles diffamatoires " publiés contre sa famille dans la capitale alsacienne étaient donc fondés.

europeana:record.dc:title: The most memorable strange tales observed from the birth of Jesus Christ to our century
Histoires prodigieuses les plus mémorables qui ayent esté observées depuis la nativité de Jésus-Christ jusques à nostre siècle
europeana:record.dc:creator: Boaistuau, Pierre (1517?-1566)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Merveilleux
europeana:record.dc:description: Pierre Boaistuau read law at several French universities before travelling a long time throughout Europe in the service of various ambassadors, allowing him to observe the contemporary world’s curiosities. Back in Paris, he wrote and published his entire œuvre between 1556 and 1560, originating two genres that dominated the second half of the 16th century: the tragic tale and the strange tale. The Histoires prodigieuses, or strange tales, on display here, the last work published in his lifetime, are mostly based on Conrad Lycosthenes and compile several sources, contemporary accounts of myths, monstrous births, horror stories and medieval tales combined with Boaistuau’s own observations. The tales, illustrated by 49 woodcuts of monsters and bizarre events, were republished, adapted and translated many times.

Après avoir étudié le droit dans plusieurs universités françaises, Pierre Boaistuau voyagea longuement à travers l’Europe au service de différents ambassadeurs, ce qui lui permit d’examiner les curiosités du monde contemporain. De retour à Paris, il rédigea et publia toute son œuvre entre 1556 et 1560. Ses livres sont à l’origine de deux genres dominants de la seconde moitié du XVIe siècle : l’histoire tragique et l’histoire prodigieuse. Les Histoires prodigieuses présentées ici, dernier ouvrage paru de son vivant, sont largement inspirées de Conrad Lycosthenes et compilent plusieurs sources, des récits contemporains de naissances monstrueuses, des histoires fantastiques, des textes mythologiques et des contes médiévaux, qui se mêlent aux propres observations de Boaistuau. Illustrées de quarante-neuf gravures sur bois, qui représentent des monstres et des événements prodigieux, les Histoires seront souvent rééditées, adaptées et traduites.

europeana:record.dc:title: Instruments for the restoration of astronomy
Tychonis Brahe astronomiae instauratae mechanica
europeana:record.dc:creator: Brahé, Tycho (1546-1601)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Astronomie de la Renaissance -- Danemark
europeana:record.dc:description: Tycho Brahe (1546-1601) studied heavenly bodies and the moon’s movement at the observatory he built in his native Denmark and called Uraniborg. The astronomer invented most of his instruments, including the huge wall quadrant he used to calculate the passage of heavenly bodies to within one minute of arc, a degree of precision no one had ever achieved before. But in 1597, having fallen into disgrace with the new king, Christian IV, Brahe left Denmark for Wandsbeck, near Hamburg. The astronomer needed a protector to finance his research, so he quickly finished the Mechanica begun at Uraniborg and dedicated it to Habsburg emperor Rudolph II. When the printing was over in May 1598, he gave illuminated copies with his effigy and coat of arms on the velvet binding to various personalities as gifts. The Bibliothèque Nationale owns three of them: the first in green velvet, whose recipient is unknown (Rés. V. 228); the second in blue velvet, given to Maurice of Orange-Nassau, stadhouder of Holland (Rés. V. 229); the third, also in blue velvet, which was sent to the archbishop of Salzbourg and eventually acquired by French philosopher Pierre Gassendi (Rés. V. 230, not reproduced here).

Tycho Brahé (1546-1601) étudia les astres et notamment le mouvement de la lune depuis son observatoire du château d'Uraniburg au Danemark. Il avait inventé la plupart de ses instruments, tel le grand quadrant mural qui permettait d'observer le passage des astres au méridien avec une précision d’une minute. Mais en 1597, disgracié par le nouveau roi Christian IV, il dut quitter le Danemark et s'installa à Wandsbeck, près de Hambourg. Il lui fallait un protecteur pour financer ses recherches, aussi termina-t-il rapidement la Mechanica commencée à Uraniburg pour la dédier à l’empereur Rodolphe II de Habsbourg. L'impression achevée, en mai 1598, il fit remettre des exemplaires de présent, enluminés et reliés en velours à son effigie et à ses armes, à diverses personnalités. La Bibliothèque nationale n’en possède pas moins de trois : le premier en velours vert dont on ne connaît pas le destinataire (Rés. V. 228) ; le second en velours bleu offert à Maurice d’Orange-Nassau, stadhouder de Hollande (Rés. V. 229) ; le troisième, aussi en velours bleu, envoyé à l’archevêque de Salzbourg et qui passa ensuite entre les mains du philosophe français Pierre Gassendi (Rés. V. 230, non reproduit ici).

europeana:record.dc:title: Vor dem Sturm
europeana:record.dc:creator: Fontane, Theodor
europeana:record.dc:subject: 830 Literatures of Germanic languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Germany is contributing digitised versions of well-known literary works by German authors from different centuries to "Reading Europe". The printed editions of these titles, taken from the stocks of the German National Library, were digitised. The brief of the library is to collect Germany's published cultural and scientific heritage since 1913, to preserve it for posterity and to make it accessible for use. The German National Library therefore documents the intellectual and literary output of the German-speaking countries. Subject librarians from the library made the selections for "Reading Europe", choosing exclusively volumes which are no longer subject to copyright.

Deutschlands Beitrag zu "Reading Europe" sind die Digitalisate von bekannten literarischen Werken deutscher Autoren aus allen Jahrhunderten. Digitalisiert wurden die Druckausgaben dieser Titel aus dem Bestand der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek, die das kulturelle und wissenschaftliche Erbe Deutschlands in seiner ab 1913 veröffentlichten Form sammelt, es für immer bewahrt und für die Nutzung zugänglich macht. Die Deutsche Nationalbibliothek dokumentiert damit das geistige und literarische Schaffen im deutschen Sprachraum. Die Auswahl für "Reading Europe" trafen Fachreferentinnen und Fachreferenten der Bibliothek, ausgewählt wurden ausschließlich Bände, die nicht mehr dem Urheberschutz unterliegen.

europeana:record.dc:title: Das Jahr in vier Gesängen, ein ländliches Epos
europeana:record.dc:creator: Donelaitis, Kristijonas
europeana:record.dc:subject: 890 Literatures of other languages
europeana:record.dc:description: This book is the first poem, written in Lithuanian language in hexameter. The poem depicts everyday life of Lithuanian peasants, their struggle with serfdom, and the annual cycle of life. Its author is Lithuanian Lutheran pastor Kristijonas Donelaitis (1714-1780). He lived and worked in Lithuanian Minor, a territory of the Kingdom of Prussia, that had a sizable minority of ethnic Lithuanians. The work was published after author's death. Edition was prepared by Liudvikas Rėza (1776-1840), using the autographs of the parts "Spring Joys" and "Summer Toils" and duplicates of "Autumn Goods" and "Winter Cares".

Ši knyga – pirmoji poema, parašyta lietuvių kalba hegzametru, apdainuojanti metų laikus. Jos autorius – Kristijonas Donelaitis (1714-1780) – buvo Tolminkiemio Evangelikų liuteronų parapijos klebonas. Veikalas išleistas gerokai po autoriaus mirties. Leidimą parengė Liudvikas Rėza (1776-1840), naudodamasis „Pavasario linksmybių“ ir „Vasaros darbų“ autografais bei „Rudenio gėrybių“ ir „Žiemos rūpesčių“ nuorašais.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: Königsberg, gedruckt in der Königl. Hartungschen Hofbuchdrukkerei
europeana:record.dc:source: Martynas Mazvydas National Library of Lithuania

europeana:record.dc:title: Giesmies swietiszkas ir szwintas
europeana:record.dc:creator: Strazdas, Antanas
europeana:record.dc:subject: 490 Other languages;890 Literatures of other languages
europeana:record.dc:description: "Giesmės svietiškos ir šventos" of the priest Antanas Strazdas (1760-1833) is the first original collection of Lithuanian poems. For a long time it was the most popular poet, and his "hymns" were sang in the whole Lithuania. His poetry was based on the principles of the Christian humanism. This edition of poems, presented in the exhibition, had been expropriated from the people, lots of copies had been burned. Just few copies remained. Works have been attacked by censors. Despite these efforts, the people liked these songs and it became the folk songs.

Kunigo Antano Strazdo (1760–1833) „Giesmės svietiškos ir šventos“ – pirmas originalių lietuviškų eilėraščių rinkinys. Ilgą laiką jis buvo populiariausias poetas, o jo „giesmes“ giedojo visa Lietuva. Jo poezija rėmėsi krikščioniško humanizmo principais. Čia pristatomas pirmasis Strazdo eilėraščių rinkinys buvo atiminėjamas iš žmonių, deginamas, jo išliko vos pora egzempliorių. Kūriniai buvo puolami cenzūros, nors labai mėgstami žmonių, tapo liaudies dainomis.
europeana:record.dc:source: Martynas Mazvydas National Library of Lithuania

europeana:record.dc:title: Couplets of Anton Vaquerizo de Morana
Coplas de Anton Vāquerizo de Morana. Y otras de. Tan buen ganadico. Y otras canciones. Y vn villancico
europeana:record.dc:subject: Literatura
europeana:record.dc:description: Since the 15th century, and throughout the whole of the 16th, the couplets of Antón, el vaquero de Morana (Antón, the cowboy of Morana) were widely distributed, especially on loose sheets, and references to its verses can be found in many literary works. The anonymous composer of this verse was very aware of a romance that, between sheets, verse and ballad collections, was extremely widely read during the 16th century. The lyrics of this period are nourished by exchanges, loans and copies for a public that was no doubt eager for this type of composition. This kind of humble notebook, in which the xylographic engravings an especially noteworthy, are difficult to find nowadays as time has meant that very few copies, of the many that must have been printed, have survived.

Desde el siglo XV, y a lo largo de todo el XVI, las coplas de Antón, el vaquero de Morana gozaron de una amplia difusión, especialmente en pliegos sueltos, y alusiones a algunos de sus versos pueden rastrearse en multitud de obras literarias. El anónimo compositor de esta versión tuvo muy en cuenta un romance que entre pliegos, cancioneros y romanceros se difundió enormemente durante el siglo XVI.. La lírica de este período se nutre de intercambios, prestamos y copias, para un público, sin duda ávido de este tipo de composiciones. Este tipo de humildes cuadernillos en los que merece especial atención el grabado xilográfico, hoy son difíciles de encontrar, pues el tiempo ha hecho que subsistan poquísimos ejemplares de los muchos que debieron estamparse.
