El 23 de noviembre de 1504, tres días antes de su muerte, la reina Isabel firma en Medina del Campo un codicilo en presencia del mismo notario, Gaspar de Gricio, y de cinco de los siete testigos que habían asistido el 12 de octubre anterior al otorgamiento y firma de su testamento. Si la reina se había referido en el testamento a los aspectos fundamentales del gobierno de los Reyes Católicos, en el codicilo, además de expresar su deseo de aprobar lo que había dispuesto en el testamento, aborda, por un lado, cuestiones que afectan directamente al gobierno peninsular y, por otro, muestra su preocupación por la política que está ejerciendo España en América, sentando las bases de las Leyes de Indias. El deseo de la reina, que disponía en la última cláusula del testamento el traslado del mismo y del codicilo original al monasterio de Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe, no se verá cumplido, pues se sabe que entre los años 1543 y 1545 el testamento se llevó al Archivo de Simancas, y el codicilo, que extrañamente se había desgajado del testamento, se incorpora a la Biblioteca Real, formando parte de un tomo de varios (T. 301) del que se separa en 1881. Actualmente se conserva en la Biblioteca Nacional. El codicilo comienza con una breve salutación a la divinidad para ratificar a continuación lo expresado en el testamento. Siguen las diecisiete cláusulas que constituyen el cuerpo del codicilo y la rúbrica de la reina con los restos del sello de placa real. Finaliza el documento con la suscripción notarial y las firmas y sellos de los cinco testigos. Escrito en letra humanística-cortesana en tres hojas de pergamino con una hoja más que sirve de cubierta, tendría el codicilo en su estado original un aspecto similar al testamento, a pesar de la pérdida del sello de placa real y de haber sido desencuadernado en 1969.

europeana:record.dc:title: Rich Missal of Cardinal Francisco Ximenez de Cisneros
Missale secundum consuetudinem almae ecclesiae Toletanae
europeana:record.dc:creator: Iglesia Católica
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: A liturgical manuscript written in Gothic script, known by the name of Misal rico de Cisneros (Rich missal of Cisneros). It belongs to the school of Toledo and is considered, along with the missal of Infantado, to be the most representative example of this school and of Castilian miniatures from the first third of the 16th century. Commissioned by Cardinal Francisco Jiménez de Cisneros for the Primate Cathedral of Toledo, it was the missal used in said cathedral until the Council of Trent came into force. It entered the Biblioteca Nacional together with other cathedral assets by virtue of the decreto de incautación (decree of seizure) of 1869. The execution of the manuscript is documented in the Libros de obra y fábrica de la catedral (Cathedral books of works and fabrication), which recorded details from 1504 to 1519. This fact enables us to know the materials used, the artists involved and the cost of the work. In this way, we know that the directives and text of the work are the responsibility of Gonzalo de Córdoba. In the illumination of the text, which had already began in 1504, almost immediately after the execution of each volume, Fernando de Jaén participates almost exclusively at the beginning, and Bernardino de Canderroa and Alonso Váquez, from the beginning until the end of its execution. This does not mean that there was no later participation by other artists. The binding was entrusted to the bookseller Juan de Santa Catalina, who established the work plan, in force until its conclusion. In 1508 he is followed by Gonzalo Rodríguez, cathedral bookbinder since 1503 and binder of the second volume. The third is the work of Fernando de Santa Catalina, and the last volumes, produced between 1545 and 1519, are by Diego Valera.

Manuscrito litúrgico, escrito en letra gótica, conocido por el nombre de Misal rico de Cisneros. Pertenece a la escuela toledana y está considerado, junto con el del Infantado, el más representativo de esa escuela y de la miniatura castellana del primer tercio del siglo XVI. Realizado por encargo del cardenal Francisco Jiménez de Cisneros a la catedral Primada de Toledo, fue el misal de uso de la misma hasta la entrada en vigor del Concilio de Trento. Se incorpora a la Biblioteca Nacional junto con otros fondos de la catedral en virtud del decreto de incautación de 1869. La realización del manuscrito está documentada en los «Libros de obra y fábrica de la catedral», constando sus datos desde 1504 hasta 1519. Este hecho nos permite conocer los materiales que se emplearon, los artistas que intervinieron y el coste de la obra. De este modo, sabemos que las directrices y el texto de la obra son responsabilidad de Gonzalo de Córdoba. En la iluminación del texto, comenzada ya en 1504, de forma casi inmediata a la realización de cada tomo, intervinieron de forma casi exclusiva Fernando de Jaén, al comienzo, y Bernardino de Canderroa y Alonso Váquez, desde el inicio hasta el final el final de la ejecución. Esto no significa que no haya intervenciones posteriores, realizadas por otros artistas. La encuadernación fue encomendada al librero Juan de Santa Catalina, que establece el plan de obra, vigente hasta su término. Le sucede, en 1508, Gonzalo Rodríguez, encuadernador de la catedral desde 1503 y del segundo tomo. El tercero es obra de Fernando de Santa Catalina, y los últimos, realizados entre 1514 y 1519, son de Diego Valera.

europeana:record.dc:title: History of the Indies of New Spain
Historia de las Indias de Nueva España e islas de la tierra firme
europeana:record.dc:creator: Durán, Diego
europeana:record.dc:subject: Geografía e Historia
europeana:record.dc:description: The work, with 101 chapters, is divided into three parts or treatises: The first contains the history of Mexico, from its origins to the conquest by Cortés and his expedition to Las Hibueras, Honduras. The second is dedicated to the Mexican gods, rituals, festivities and temples; and the third to the Aztec calendar. It is illustrated with over one hundred, quill-drawn miniatures which represent scenes from the text, mostly located in the chapter headers; some are cut-outs that belonged to another book. Copied from local, indigenous models, they contain scenes of high ethnographical value regarding the history of Mexico before and after the conquest. Brother Diego, like other missionaries, undoubtedly wrote his history to assist in teaching and evangelising the Indians; to do so, it was necessary to know them beforehand, as “for as much work as is put into it”, assures the Dominican monk, nothing would be achieved without knowing “all the types of religion in which they lived”. And thus, by observing the customs of the natives (rituals, dances, chants, festivities…), he left us a detailed vision of the indigenous world gathered shortly after the conquest, which makes this a firsthand source and compulsory text for ethnographers and historians.

La obra, con 101 capítulos, esta dividida en tres partes o tratados: el primero contiene la historia de México, desde su origen hasta la conquista de Cortés y la expedición de éste a las Hibueras. El segundo, esta dedicado a los dioses mexicanos, ritos, festividades y templos; y el tercero, al calendario azteca. Está ilustrado con más de cien miniaturas, dibujadas a pluma y coloreadas, que representan escenas referentes al texto, situadas la mayoría en la cabecera de los capítulos; algunas, son recortes pegados que pertenecieron a otra obra. Realizadas copiando modelos indígenas, contienen escenas de gran valor etnográfico, referentes a la historia de México anterior y posterior a la conquista. Fray Diego, como otros misioneros, escribió sin duda su historia para ayudar a la enseñanza y evangelización de los indios; para ello había que conocerlos previamente, pues “por mucho trabajo que en ello se ponga”, asegura el fraile dominico, nada se conseguiría sin saber “todos los modos de religión en que vivían”. Y así, al observar las costumbres de los naturales: ritos, bailes, cantares, fiestas…, nos ha dejado una detallada visión del mundo indígena recogida poco después de la conquista, que la convierte en fuente de primera mano y de obligada consulta para etnólogos e historiadores.

europeana:record.dc:title: Curial and Guelfa
Amors de Curial e Güelfa
europeana:record.dc:subject: Literatura
europeana:record.dc:description: An anonymous romance novel, comparable to Tirant lo Blanch (Tirant the White), that narrates the adventures of Sir Curial and his beloved Güelfa. It was written between 1435 and 1462. The psychological component that subordinates the main characters, differentiating it from the common romance novels, turns this into one of the most outstanding works of our literature. Despite the name of the author being unknown, we do know that he was Catalonian and an avid reader, especially of the classics. The French and Italian influences are clear, with the incorporation of elements from the Arthurian cycle, from Bocaccio's Fiametta (whose resemblance to Güelfa is evident), as well as certain passages that remind us of Dante, Aristotle, Virgil or Ovid, among others, which have caused doubts about its origin, bringing it closer to an Italian context. This fact led to conjectures that author was possibly related to the court of Naples of Alfonso V, where he may have spent time and written his work. In turn, Curial possesses all the qualities of the ancient knight: Strong, valiant, generous… This work has been conserved in this single manuscript, on paper formed by sections of twelve sheets and one of eight. It conserves the notes by the amanuensis for its later ordering, as well as indications on the capitals for the miniaturist, which were finally not executed. It is divided into three books of 47, 147 and 107 chapters each, whose content, according to Martín de Riquer, reveals the author's audacity when we read in the third book: "E faç conclusió que millor partit te’n portes que no leixes a la Güelfa, segons an l’altre libre et diguí".

Novela caballeresca anónima, comparable al Tirant lo Blanc, que narra las aventuras del caballero Curial y de su amada Güelfa. Fue escrita entre 1435 y 1462. El componente psicológico que subordina a los protagonistas, diferenciándola de las novelas de caballerías corrientes, la convierte en una de las obras destacadas de nuestra literatura. A pesar de que el nombre del autor nos es desconocido, sí sabemos que era catalán y un ávido lector, especialmente de obras clásicas. Las influencias francesas e italiana son notables, con la incorporación de elementos del ciclo artúrico, de la Fiametta de Bocaccio (cuya semejanza con Güelfa es evidente), así como ciertos pasajes que recuerdan a Dante, Aristóteles, Virgilio u Ovidio, entre otros, que han hecho dudar de su origen acercándolo más a un contexto italiano. Este hecho indujo a pensar en la posible relación del autor con la corte napolitana de Alfonso V, donde pudo haber pasado temporadas y escrito su obra. Curial, por su parte, posee todas las virtudes del antiguo caballero: fuerte, valeroso, generoso… La obra se ha conservado en este único manuscrito en papel formado por pliegos de doce hojas y uno de ocho, conservándose las anotaciones del copista para su posterior ordenación, así como las indicaciones de las capitales para el miniaturista, que, finalmente, no se llegaron a realizar. Está dividido en tres libros de 47, 147 y 107 capítulos cada uno, cuyo contenido, como señaló Martín de Riquer, revela la audacia del autor cuando leemos en el libro tercero: «E faç conclusió que millor partit te’n portes que no leixes a la Güelfa, segons an l’altre libre et diguí».

europeana:record.dc:title: Breviary of love
Le breviari d'amor . Inc.: Per ço cascun lo seny e l'enteniment (h. I)... Exp.: Finito libro sit laus et gloria Christo. Amen (h. CLXIIIIv)
europeana:record.dc:creator: Ermengaud, Matfré
europeana:record.dc:subject: Literatura
europeana:record.dc:description: Illuminated manuscript dating from between the end of the 14th century and the beginning of the 15th. It is one of the complete translations conserved of the original text, believed to be written after 1288 in the Languedocien dialect by Matfré Ermengaud de Béziers. The work emerges while the Catharian theories were still in force, hence the arguments and illustrations chosen by the author are aimed at defending the principles of Catholic theology on God, Christ, the Trinity, the Virgin, etc. It also introduces observations on society of the time, using elements similar to those used by minstrels. A work that was very widely read in Europe, particularly in France and in the Kingdom of Aragon. Six of the remaining manuscripts, including this one, come from the Catalonian field of phonology, some in Eastern Catalan and others in Western. A didactic poem on human and divine love, developed from an allegory at the beginning of the poem: The allegory of the Arbre d’Amor (Tree of Love) (p. 3v.). It is in the style of other contemporary summas, to deal with matters such as geography, physics, astronomy, astrology, natural history, etc.; but with limited scientific rigour. It consists of a prose fragment at the beginning that explains the miniature of the Arbre d’Amor; this is followed by rhymes formed by eight-syllable two-line verses and lastly, as an appendix, it ends with ten-syllable two-line verses. Four cover sheets are added to this structure, one at the beginning and three at the end. They conserve fragments of other codices. One contains a 14th century poem attributed to Ermengaud; the others are from the 13th century and correspond to a Latin codex with musical notations.

Manuscrito iluminado, datado entre finales del siglo XIV y comienzos del XV. Es una de las traducciones completas que se conservan del texto original, escrito en languedociano por Matfré Ermengaud de Béziers, se cree que a partir de 1288. La obra surge estando aún vigentes las teorías cátaras, de ahí que los argumentos e ilustraciones elegidos por el autor se destinen a defender los principios de la teología católica, sobre Dios, Cristo, la Trinidad, la Virgen, etc. Además introduce observaciones sobre la sociedad de su época, sirviéndose, de elementos semejantes a los empleados por los juglares. Obra de gran difusión en Europa, especialmente en Francia y el reino de Aragón. Seis de los manuscritos conservados, incluido éste, provienen del ámbito fonológico catalán, unos del catalán oriental y otros del occidental. Poema didáctico sobre el amor humano y divino, desarrollado a partir de una alegoría al comienzo del poema: la alegoría del Arbre d’Amor (h. 3v.). Se sitúa en el estilo de otras summas contemporáneas, para abordar materias como geografía, física, astronomía, astrología, historia natural, etc.; pero con escaso rigor científico. Se compone de un fragmento en prosa al comienzo, que explica la miniatura del Arbre d’Amor; le siguen rimas formadas por octosílabos pareados y, por último, a modo de apéndice, finaliza con decasílabos también pareados. A esta estructura se añaden cuatro hojas de guarda, una al comienzo y tres al final, que conservan fragmentos de otros códices. Uno de ellos contiene una poesía del siglo XIV atribuida a Ermengaud; los otros son del siglo XIII y corresponden a un códice latino con notación musical.

europeana:record.dc:title: Grammar
Граматика
europeana:record.dc:creator: Смотрицки, Мелетиј
europeana:record.dc:subject: 400 - Language
europeana:record.dc:description: The first grammar adapted for modern Serbian schools.
Прва граматика прилагођена за српске школе новијег доба.

europeana:record.dc:title: Devotional
Devocionario
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: A manuscript written in 15th century France, which comes from the Library of the Count of Haro, whose shield appears on an initial border with Hispano-Flemish decoration and floral garland. The work contains: Appología super psalmum Iudice. Doulceur de amour et amour de doulceur. Missa de Sacramento Domini. Service of the Holy Sacrament, wrongly titled “De ascensiones domini. Capitula”. Die Iovis. Officium de sacramenti.

Manuscrito escrito en Francia en el S.XV, procedente de la Biblioteca del Conde de Haro, cuyo escudo figura en una orla inicial, con decoración hispano-flamenca y guirnalda floral. La obra contiene: Appología super psalmum Iudice. Doulceur de amour et amour de doulceur. Missa de Sacramento Domini. Oficio del Santísimo Sacramento, con título equivocado “De ascensiones domini. Capitula”. Die Iovis. Officium de sacramenti.

europeana:record.dc:title: Book of judges
Forum iudicum, Tabulae Chronologicae, Canones Ecclesiae et Opuscula Grammaticae
europeana:record.dc:subject: Derecho. Administración Pública
europeana:record.dc:description: The legislative body that ruled in the Spanish kingdoms during the Visigoth period is known by the name Fuero Juzgo. The manuscript presented here comes from the Cathedral of León. It informs us that it was made by the amanuensis Froila for Presbyter Munnio. It is written in lower case Visigoth letters and is attributed to the School of León. It has beautiful ornamentation with borders and initials, with a clear Mozarabic influence, noticeable on the lattices and the presence of horseshoe arches.

Con el nombre de Fuero Juzgo se conoce al cuerpo legislativo de legal que rigió en los reinos hispánicos durante el período visigodo. El manuscrito aquí presentado procede de la Catedral de León. En él se nos informa de que fue realizado por el copista Froila para el presbítero Munnio. Está escrito en letra visigótica minúscula y se atribuye a la escuela leonesa. Cuenta con una bella ornamentación a base de orlas e iniciales, de clara influencia mozárabe, apreciable en las lacerías y en la presencia de arcos de herradura.

europeana:record.dc:title: Pontifical of Guillaume Durand
Pontifical de Guillaume Durand: para uso de Don Luís de Acuña, Obispo de Burgos
europeana:record.dc:creator: Iglesia Católica
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: Manuscript from the second half of the 15th century. Written in Castile. A typical Roman Pontifical from the church of Burgos. It belonged to Luis de Acuña y Osorio, bishop of Burgos from the year 1457 until 1495. Abundant illumination and outstanding miniatures. The illuminations on p. XII are worthy of mention: Bordered with plant and animal decoration and a half-page representation of the donning of the pontifical ornaments, the upper frieze has a space for a coat of arms; on p. 22v is the Crucifixion with Jerusalem in the background, a copy of an illustration by Martin Schongauer, below on the “Te igitur” is Christ washing the feet of the Apostles; on p. 23r is the representation of Christ Pantocrator, in which we can also see the influence of Schongauer in the frieze, the coat of arms with five wounds, in remembrance of the Franciscan devotion of Luis de Acuña. Initials decorated with pontifical scenes such as the confirmation of a child by the bishop, ordaining of priests, of a reader, of an exorcist, of acolytes, the coronation of the King by the bishop, the consecration of a church, etc. It has square Gregorian musical notation, set in 5 red lines and it contains the Roman melody of all the pieces destined to be sung.

Manuscrito de la segunda mitad del S.XV. Escrito en Castilla. Pontifical al uso de la iglesia de Burgos. Perteneció a Luis de Acuña y Osorio, obispo de Burgos, desde el año 1457 hasta 1495. Iluminación profusa y notables miniaturas. Destacan las iluminaciones de la h. XII orlada con decoración vegetal y animal, y representación a media página de la vestición de los ornamentos pontificales, en el friso inferior hueco para un escudo; en la h. 22v se escenifica la Crucifixión con Jerusalén como fondo, copia de una estampa de Martin Schongauer, debajo en el “Te igitur” Cristo lavando los pies a los Apóstoles; en la h. 23r se representa el Pantocrator y en él se reconoce también la influencia de Schongauer,, en el friso, escudo con cinco llagas, en recuerdo de la devoción franciscana de Luis de Acuña. Capitales historiadas con escenas del pontifical como la confirmación de un niño por el obispo, ordenación de clérigos, de lector, de exorcista, de acólitos, coronación del Rey por el obispo, consagración de una iglesia, etc. Tiene notación musical gregoriana cuadrada, pautados de 5 líneas en rojo y contiene la melodía romana de todas las piezas que están destinadas al canto.

europeana:record.dc:title: An introductory Latin book
Первије начатки латинскога језика
europeana:record.dc:creator: Orfelin, Zaharija
europeana:record.dc:subject: 400 - Language
europeana:record.dc:description: One of the first Latin textbooks
Један од првих уџбеника латинског језика.

europeana:record.dc:title: Psalter (h. 1-156). Book of hours (h. 157-220)
Salterio (h. 1-156). Libro de Horas (h. 157-220)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: Preceded by a calendar (p. 1-6) with representations of the monthly tasks, it has a note from the owner on the last cover page that says: Chest a Colnet Lamquier de la Ville d'Amiens demourant en la rue des Tripes. ¬ It was written in the north of France. The Book of Psalms is decorated with large miniatures of David, the Resurrection, Saint Francis and Saint Dominic, and Initials with the figure of the psalmist. Richly miniaturised with burnished gold. The Book of Hours has large capital letters that represent the Annunciation, scenes from the Passion and the burial service. It belonged to Cardinal Zelada and comes from Toledo Cathedral. It is one of the most important liturgical manuscripts in the Biblioteca Nacional.

Precedido de un calendario (h. 1-6) con una representación de los trabajos de los meses, tiene una nota del poseedor en la última hoja de guarda que dice: Chest a Colnet Lamquier de la Ville d'Amiens demourant en la rue des Tripes. ¬ Fue Escrito en el norte de Francia. El Salterio está decorado con grandes miniaturas de David, Resurreción, San Francisco y Santo Domingo e Iniciales con la figura del salmista. Todo ricamente miniado, con fondos de oro bruñido. El Libro de Horas tiene grandes capitales que representan la Anunciación, escenas de la Pasión, y oficio de la sepultura. Perteneció al cardenal Zelada y procede de la Catedral de Toledo. Es uno de los más importantes manuscritos litúrgicos de la Biblioteca Nacional.

europeana:record.dc:title: Of the city of God
De civitate Dei
europeana:record.dc:creator: Agustín, Santo, Obisbo de Hipona
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: This parchment codex is incomplete at the beginning and begins a little before chapter XVI of the Libro II de la Ciudad de Dios (2nd Book of the City of God). Carefully copied and illuminated in a style approaching the Romanesque Castilian-Leonese School, it contains beautiful initials with fantasy or monstrous creatures, sometimes in subdued colours and others, the most beautiful, are monochromatic. It is one of the most representative works of Romanesque art in the Biblioteca Nacional.

Este códice en pergamino, está incompleto al principio y comienza poco antes del capítulo XVI del Libro II de la Ciudad de Dios. Cuidadosamente copiado e iluminado en un estilo próximo a la escuela castellano-leonesa románica, contiene preciosas iniciales con seres fantásticos o monstruosos, a veces con colores tenues y otras, las más bellas, monócromas, y es uno de los más representativos del pleno arte románico de la Biblioteca Nacional.

europeana:record.dc:title: Devotional book of Isabel de Valois
Devocionario de Isabel de Valois
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: This manuscript was one of the prayer books of Queen Elisabeth de Valois, third wife of Philip II. During the 15th and 16th centuries, there was a special prosperity in the elaboration of this type of codices, which were personalised for the figures from the highest ranks of the aristocracy with great luxury in the materials and ornamental elements employed. However,the manuscript presented here stands out for the sober decoration with which it is conceived. The ornamentation is reduced to simple gold, ochre and vermilion frames on each page, red epigraphs and signatures and miniaturised initials and finishing touches to the lines. On the first page we find an ochre background decorated with pearls, an inscription in capital letters with the name of the book's owner: «Helysabet Hispaniae Regina». The codex presents crossed out prayers, as a consequence of the censorship that the text was subjected to by the Inquisition in the year 1573.

Este manuscrito fue uno de los libros de oraciones de la reina Isabel de Valois, tercera esposa de Felipe II. Durante los siglos XV y XVI, se dio un especial florecimiento en la elaboración de este tipo de códices, que se realizaron de forma personalizada para los personajes de la más alta aristocracia, con gran lujo de materiales y de elementos ornamentales. Sin embargo el manuscrito que aquí presentamos se destaca por la sobriedad decorativa con la que está concebido. La ornamentación se reduce a sencillos marcos de oro, ocre y bermellón encuadrando cada página, a epígrafes y rúbricas en rojo y a iniciales y remates de líneas miniados. En primera hoja encontramos, sobre fondo ocre y cuajado de perlas, una inscripción en letras capitales con el nombre de la propietaria del libro: «Helysabet Hispaniae Regina». El códice presenta algunas oraciones tachadas, como consecuencia de la censura a la que el texto fue sometido por parte de la Inquisición en el año 1573.

europeana:record.dc:title: The book of emperors (h. 1-180); The book of facts and conquests of the Principality of Morea (h. 183-266)
El libro de los emperadores (h. 1-180); El libro de los fechos et conquistas del principado de Morea (h. 183-266)
europeana:record.dc:creator: Fernández de Heredia, Juan 1308?-1396
europeana:record.dc:subject: Geografía e Historia
europeana:record.dc:description: It is an epic-historic poem which describes the French conquest of the Peloponnese and their settlement in the Principality of Morea throughout the 13th century. Four versions of this work exist. One is the one we are currently commenting, translated into the Aragonese language by Juan Fernández de Heredia, member of the Hospital Order, in which he held important posts, and prior of the Order of Castile (1355). It is decorated with gold and coloured borders and two portraits of the author; in the first, dressed in the habit of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem, and in the second, marching with his warriors to the conquest of Morea.

Es un poema épico-histórico donde se describe la conquista del Peloponeso por los franceses y su instalación en el Principado de Morea a lo largo del siglo XIII. De esta obra existen cuatro versiones. Una de ellas es la que aquí comentamos, traducida al aragonés por encargo de D. Juan Fernández de Heredia, miembro de la Orden del Hospital, en la que ocupó cargos importantes, y prior de la Orden en Castilla (1355). Esta decorada con orlas en oro y colores, y dos retratos del autor; en el primero, vestido con el hábito de la Orden de San Juan de Jerusalén, y en el segundo, marchando con sus guerreros a la conquista de Morea.

europeana:record.dc:title: Book of punishments, attributed to Sancho IV
Libro de los castigos, atribuido a Sancho IV
europeana:record.dc:subject: Geografía e Historia
europeana:record.dc:description: El libro del los castigos (The Book of Punishments), is a magnificent copy of an exemplum or compendium of moral and didactic tales, works which enjoyed a certain popularity during the Middle Ages. The authorship of this book is traditionally attributed to King Sancho IV of Castile, although it seems that he was not its material author but its sponsor. As well as the literary value of this manuscript, we must highlight the presence of numerous coloured drawings, with scenes from religious history as well as daily life, making the book valuable from an iconographical viewpoint. It also has initials decorated with red and violent ink and pilcrows in red.

El libro del los castigos, es una magnífica muestra de exemplario o compendio de cuentos morales y didácticos, obras que gozaron de cierta difusión durante la Edad Media. Tradicionalmente la autoría de este libro se atribuyó al rey Sancho IV de Castilla, aunque parece que éste no fue su autor material, sino su promotor. Además del valor literario de este manuscrito debemos reseñar que él la presencia de numerosos dibujos coloreados, con escenas de la historia religiosa, así como de la vida cotidiana, lo que le confiere un especial valor iconográfico. También presenta iniciales afiligranadas en tintas roja y violeta y calderones en rojo.

europeana:record.dc:title: Book of hours
Libro de horas
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: This codex has, on many occasions, been considered mediocre, but recently its relevance is being revindicated because of its technical perfection and the somewhat expressionist conception of the characters it portrays. It is undoubtedly Flemish, from the second half of the 15th century, and it seems to have come from the workshop of Grante, although it also has influences from the workshop of Utrech.

Este códice ha sido considerado en muchas ocasiones como una obra mediocre, pero en los últimos tiempos está siendo reivindicada su relevancia, debida a la perfección técnica que presenta y por la concepción algo expresionista de los personajes que se representan. Su factura es indudablemente flamenca, de la segunda mitad del siglo XV, y parece deberse al taller de Grante, aunque tiene también influencias del taller de Utrech.

europeana:record.dc:title: Decades
Décadas
europeana:record.dc:creator: Livio, Tito
europeana:record.dc:subject: Geografía e Historia
europeana:record.dc:description: The manuscript contains the translation into Castilian of the first three Décadas (Decades) of Tito Livio, written in the 15th century by Rodrigo Alonso de Pimentel, Count of Benavente. The book began with a prologue by the translator, which has now disappeared. It is illustrated with thirteen large, full page, colour drawings, which represent scenes from Ancient Rome. It also includes beautiful borders, decorated initials and epigraphs and pilcrows in red and blue ink. Page 4, which is today the first page of the manuscript, is lavishly illustrated and contains the coat of arms of the Count of Benavente held by an angel.

El manuscrito contiene la traducción al castellano de las tres primeras Décadas de Tito Livio, realizada en el siglo XV por don Rodrigo Alonso de Pimentel, Conde de Benavente. El libro se abría con un prólogo del traductor, que hoy ha desaparecido. Aparece ilustrado con trece grandes dibujos en color, a página completa, que representan escenas de la Antigüedad romana. Además se incluyen bellas orlas, iniciales afiligranadas y epígrafes y calderones en tinta roja y azul. El folio 4, que es hoy el primero que encontramos en el manuscrito, está profusamente ilustrado y contiene el escudo del Conde de Benavente sujeto por un ángel.

europeana:record.dc:title: Letters to the Kings of Aragon, Castille and Portugal
Cartas a los Reyes de Aragón, Castilla y Portugal
europeana:record.dc:creator: Evreux y Trastámara, Carlos d', Príncipe de Viana 1421-1461
europeana:record.dc:subject: Literatura
europeana:record.dc:description: This manuscript contains some letters that Fernando Bolea y Galloz, secretary of the Prince of Viana, Don Carlos de Aragón, sent to the kings and queens of Aragon, Castile and Portugal. In these letters, Bolea transmits the philosophical and moral ideas of his master and shows us his studious nature, which drove him to become an outstanding cultural and artistic patron in his court. This codex was copied by Antonio Aznar in the year 1480, on fine calfskin paper. But its main attraction is its portrait of Don Carlos de Aragón. We do not know who its author was, but it seems clear that he worked clearly under the influence of the Burgundy art of the time. The figure of the prince is presented full-body, with a greyhound lying at his feet, and wearing the emblem of the Order of the Griffon on his breast. The ornamentation of the codex includes decorative strokes, as well as a beautiful initial decorated with vegetable motifs and blue and red capitals.

Este manuscrito contiene algunas cartas que Fernando Bolea y Galloz, secretario del Príncipe de Viana, don Carlos de Aragón, dirige a los reyes de Aragón, Castilla y Portugal. En ellas, Bolea transmite las ideas filosóficas y morales de su señor y nos muestra el carácter erudito que éste tuvo y que le impulsó a ejercer un destacado mecenazgo cultural y artístico en su corte. El códice fue copiado por Antonio Aznar, en el año 1480, sobre hojas de fina vitela. Pero su principal atractivo lo constituye el retrato de don Carlos de Aragón que incluye. Desconocemos quién fue su autor, pero parece claro que trabajó con una clara influencia del arte borgoñón de la época. La figura del príncipe se presenta de cuerpo entero, con un galgo tendido a sus pies y luciendo la enseña de la orden del Grifo en su pecho. La ornamentación del códice incluye además una bella inicial decorada con motivos vegetales y capitales en azul y rojo, con decoración de rasgueo.

europeana:record.dc:title: Book of hours in the Roman tradition
Libro de horas, según el uso de Roma
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: A beautiful manuscript created according to the style marked by the Parisian school of illumination during the 15th century. Although the high quality of this codex is reflected in the writing as well as the quality of the parchment used, its ornamentation is what is most outstanding. We find this on all the pages of the manuscript, using borders with plant decorations, using gold and different coloured inks. The initials also reflect this chromatic diversity. But it also includes half page miniatures which represent scenes from the life of Jesus Christ. The authorship of this work was initially attributed to Jacquemart de Hesdin, but later the illuminations have been attributed to different artists linked to the workshops of the Master of Egerton, and the Master of Boucicaut.

Bello manuscrito elaborado de acuerdo con el estilo marcado por la escuela parisina de iluminación durante el siglo XV. Aunque la alta calidad de este códice se refleja tanto en la escritura como en la finura del pergamino utilizado, lo que más destaca en él es la ornamentación. Esta la encontramos en todas las páginas del manuscrito, mediante orlas con decoración vegetal, en las que se utiliza el oro y las tintas de diversos colores. También las iniciales reflejan esta diversidad cromática. Pero además se incluyen miniaturas a media página en las que se nos presentan escenas de la vida de Jesucristo. En un principio se atribuyó la autoría de esta obra a Jacquemart de Hesdin, pero posteriormente las iluminaciones han sido atribuidas a artistas diversos, relacionados con los talleres del Maestro de Egerton, y del Maestro de Boucicaut.

europeana:record.dc:title: Hymn to the Trinity
Himno a la Trinidad
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: A manuscript of exceptional interest for the language in which it is written and its illuminations. It is a brief religious text, written in the extinct Ge’ez language, which was spoken in ancient times in Ethiopia and has been conserved to this day for liturgical uses. The text is accompanied by some eye-catching miniatures which, with clear oriental influences, represent scenes related to the Annunciation of the Virgin Mary, the Holy Trinity and the twelve apostles. Formally, the manuscript is made up of a single sheet of parchments, long and folded into an accordion, which is protected by two loose leather covers and decorated with dry irons.

Manuscrito de excepcional interés por la lengua en la que está escrito y por sus iluminaciones. Se trata de un breve texto religioso, escrito en la extinta lengua ge’ez, que se habó en Etiopía en la Antigüedad y que se ha conservado hasta hoy para uso litúrgico. El texto va acompañado por unas vistosas miniaturas en las que, con clara influencia oriental, se representan escenas relacionadas con la Anunciación de la Virgen, con la Trinidad y con los doce apóstoles. Formalmente, el manuscrito está constituido por una única hoja de pergamino, alargada y plegada en forma de acordeón, que se protege por dos tapas de cuero sueltas y decoradas con hierros secos.

europeana:record.dc:title: Guillaume de Rollin book of hours
Libro de horas de Rollin
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: Los libros de horas (The books of hours) appear in the 13th century, but it would be in the 15th when they would reach their greatest splendour. They are books of prayer, conceived to be read in person and in private by their owners so therefore, on most occasions, they are made by commission for a certain person. They are made as luxury items, for people from the nobility, and their main characteristics are the lavishness and beauty of their illustrations. The manuscript that we present here was made in Flanders for Guillaume de Rollin. It is illuminated with grisaille, which represent scenes from the life of Christ and several saints. It also includes several initials decorated with the coat of arms of the Rollin family (three gold keys on a blue background) and some in polished gold and with calligraphic decoration. There is no consensus among researchers on the artist, as sometimes it is attributed to Alejandor Bening and in others to Simon Marmion. On page 3 we find a miniature that must have been created at a later date, clearly lower in quality than the rest of the illustrations.

Los libros de horas surgen en el siglo XIII, pero será en el siglo XV cuando alcancen su mayor esplendor. Son libros de oración, concebidos para ser leídos de forma particular y privada por sus propietarios, por lo que, en la mayoría de las ocasiones, se realizan por encargo, para una persona determinada. Se confeccionan como objetos de lujo, destinados a personajes de la alta nobleza y sus principales características son la profusión y belleza de las ilustraciones que incluyen. El manuscrito que aquí presentamos fue realizado, en Flandes, para el caballero Guillaume de Rollin. Está iluminado mediante grisallas, en las que se representan escenas de la vida de Cristo y de diversos santos. Además incluye varias iniciales decoradas con las armas de los Rollin (tres llaves de oro en campo azul) y algunas realizadas en oro bruñido y con decoración caligráfica. Sobre el artista que lo realizó no hay unanimidad entre los investigadores, ya que en algunos casos se ha atribuido a Alejandor Bening y en otros a Simon Marmion. En la hoja 3 encontramos una miniatura que debió ser realizada con posterioridad y de una calidad visiblemente inferior a la del resto de ilustraciones.

europeana:record.dc:title: Ketubah
Ketubá
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: Hebrew manuscript, in the form of a scroll, which contains the marriage contract between Mordekay, son of David, from Sicily, and Gentilisca, daughter of Jacob, from Ciprano. It is dated the 13th of Sivan 5429 (which corresponds to the year 1669 of our era), in Rome. The scripture presented is a beautiful Sephardic square. It is decorated with borders with plant motifs, initials in red, green and blue and with the representation of a lion among floral decorations at the bottom. The scroll is conserved in a cylindrical case lined with red leather and decorated in gold. The document comes from Toledo Cathedral.

Manuscrito hebreo, en forma de rollo, que contiene el contrato matrimonial, entre Mordekay, hijo de David, de Sicilia, y Gentilisca, hija de Jacob, de Ciprano. Está fechado el 13 de Siván de 5429 (correspondiente con el año 1669 de nuestra era), en Roma. La escritura que presenta es una hermosa sefardí cuadrada. Está decorado con orlas de motivos vegetales, con iniciales en colores rojo, verde y azul y con la representación de un león entre decoraciones florales en la parte inferior. El rollo se conserva en un estuche cilíndrico forrado con piel roja y adornado con dorados. El documento procede de la Catedral de Toledo.

europeana:record.dc:title: Arabic scholar tablet
Tabla escolar árabe
europeana:record.dc:subject: Educación. Enseñanza
europeana:record.dc:description: Hebrew manuscript, in the form of a roll, which contains the marriage contract between Mordekay, son of David, from Sicily, and Gentilisca, daughter of Jacob, from Ciprano. It is dated the 13th of Sivan 5429 (which corresponds to the year 1669 of our era), in Rome. The writing is a beautiful Sephardi square. It is decorated with borders with plant motifs, initials in red, green and blue and with the representation of a lion among floral decorations at the bottom. The roll is conserved in a cylindrical case lined with red leather and decorated in gold. The document comes from Toledo Cathedral.

Manuscrito hebreo, en forma de rollo, que contiene el contrato matrimonial, entre Mordekay, hijo de David, de Sicilia, y Gentilisca, hija de Jacob, de Ciprano. Está fechado el 13 de Siván de 5429 (correspondiente con el año 1669 de nuestra era), en Roma. La escritura que presenta es una hermosa sefardí cuadrada. Está decorado con orlas de motivos vegetales, con iniciales en colores rojo, verde y azul y con la representación de un león entre decoraciones florales en la parte inferior. El rollo se conserva en un estuche cilíndrico forrado con piel roja y adornado con dorados. El documento procede de la Catedral de Toledo.

europeana:record.dc:title: Book of hours
Libro de horas
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: Small parchment manuscript from the second half of the 15th century, written in Flemish. Luxuriously miniaturised, it is the work of the Flemish illuminator Master of Mary of Burgundy. It comprises a calendar, in French, with the illustration of each month which occupies both sides of the page. The scenes are located in a box in the margins of the text, only interrupting the borders. These is turn are decorated with extremely delicate miniatures that represent birds, flowers, fruit and insects, on a background of matt gold or colour with touches of gold. The lower border contains scenes with the tasks of the month and the signs of the zodiac, microscopical in size and admirably executed. The calendar is followed by the hours of the Cross, the Holy Spirit, the Virgin Mary, prayers, litanies.

Pequeño códice en pergamino, de la segunda mitad del siglo XV, escrito en Flandes. Lujosamente miniado, es obra del gran iluminador flamenco Maestro de María de Borgoña. Consta de un calendario, en lengua francesa, con la ilustración de cada mes que ocupa el recto y verso del folio. Las escenas están alojadas en un recuadro en los márgenes del texto, interrumpiendo el desarrollo de las orlas. Éstas, a su vez, aparecen decoradas con delicadísimas miniaturas que representan, aves, flores, frutas e insectos, sobre fondo de oro mate o de color con toques de oro. En la orla inferior, escenas referentes a los trabajos de los meses, y los signos del Zodíaco, en tamaño microscópico y de admirable ejecución. Al calendario le siguen las horas de la Cruz, del Espíritu Santo, de la Virgen María, oraciones, letanías.

europeana:record.dc:title: Various treaties and epistles
Tratados y epístolas varios
europeana:record.dc:creator: Morales, Ambrosio de
europeana:record.dc:subject: Religión
europeana:record.dc:description: This manuscript is important because of its compilatory nature, as it gathers copies of important historical works, such as the Corpus Pelagianum, the works of King Sisebut, St. Isidore and ancient documents and curiosities. Our manuscript was copied in the 16th century by order of the humanist and historian Ambrosio de Morales. It collects copies of the historical works referring to Spain and taken from medieval codices, such as the no longer existing "Códice Ovetense" (made by order of the Bishop of Oviedo, Don Pelayo), the "Códice Complutense" (copied in the 12th century, probably in the monastery of San Juan de Corias) or the "Códice Batriense" (copied in the 13th century and which belonged to the poet Garcilaso de la Vega). The manuscript closes with a privilege of donation for which St. Ferdinand bestowed the Order of Calatrava with the towns of Martos, Porcuna and Víboras and with the Historia Arabum of Don Rodrigo, Bishop of Toledo, taken from the aforementioned "Códice Complutense". The manuscript contains a family tree of the Spanish kings and queens and illustrations representing the cross of the angels, wheels and stamps.

La relevancia de este manuscrito deriva de su carácter compilatorio, ya que recoge copias de importantes obras históricas, como el Corpus Pelagianus, obras del rey Sisebuto, de San Isidoro y de San Julián y escritos y curiosidades antiguas. Nuestro manuscrito fue copiado en el siglo XVI por encargo del humanista e historiador Ambrosio de Morales. En él se recogen copias de obras históricas referidas a España y tomadas de códices medievales, como el hoy desaparecido «Códice Ovetense» (realizado por orden del Obispo de Oviedo, don Pelayo), el «Códice Complutense» (copiado en el siglo XII, probablemente en el monasterio de San Juan de Corias) o el «Códice Batriense» (copiado en el siglo XIII y que perteneció al poeta Garcilaso de la Vega). El manuscrito se cierra con un privilegio de donación por el que San Fernando otorgó a la Orden de Calatrava las villas de Martos, Porcuna y Víboras y con la Historia Arabum de don Rodrigo, obispo de Toledo, tomada del ya citado «Códice Complutense». El manuscrito contiene un árbol genealógico de los reyes hispánicos e ilustraciones a pluma representando la cruz de los ángeles, ruedas y sellos.

europeana:record.dc:title: Triumph of Emperor Maximilian I, King of Hungary, Dalmatia and Croatia, Archduke of Austria

Triunfo del Emperador Maximiliano I, Rey de Hungría, Dalmacia y Croacia, Archiduque de Austria [Manuscrito] :... de quien están descritas y colocadas en esta colección las acciones gloriosas de S.M. Imperial, durante su vida
europeana:record.dc:subject: Bellas Artes
europeana:record.dc:description: This manuscript has the form of a splendid album of 87 vellum pages, in which we can find rich miniatures which represent the entourage of Emperor Maximilian, made up of his family, princes and princesses from the House of Austria and Court employees in general (jesters, musicians, hunters, etc.). The figures and scenes are identified by legends written in German. It would appear that they are copies made from the drawings that the Emperor commissioned from artists of the standing of Durero and Albrecht Altdorfe. Some of these copies are also kept in the Albertina Library in Vienna. Those which are conserved in the Biblioteca Nacional in Spain seem to have been made upon the request of Archduke Albert of Austria. The luxurious binding of the manuscript is also outstanding, made from brown leather, decorated with dry irons, in keeping with the French style of the time of Louis XV and with corner pieces and metal shields and coats of arms of the Grand Master and Knight of the Teutonic Order.

Este manuscrito se configura como un espléndido álbum de 87 hojas en vitela, en las que encontramos ricas miniaturas que representan el cortejo del Emperador Maximiliano, integrado por personajes de su familia, príncipes y princesas de la Casa de Austria y empleados de la Corte en general (bufones, músicos, cazadores, etc.). Las figuras y escenas están identificadas por leyendas escritas en alemán. Parece que se trata de copias realizadas a partir de los dibujos que el Emperador encargó a artistas de la talla de Durero y Albrecht Altdorfe. De estas copias se conservan también ejemplares en la Biblioteca Albertina de Viena. Las que se conservan en la Biblioteca Nacional de España parece que fueron hechas a petición del archiduque Alberto de Austria. También destaca la lujosa encuadernación del manuscrito, hecha en piel marrón, decorada con hierros secos, según el estilo francés de la época de Luis XV y con cantoneras y escudos metálicos y blasones del Gran Maestre y de un caballero de la Orden Teutónica.

europeana:record.dc:title: Painting of the governor, mayors and administrators of Mexico, Osuna Codex
Pintura del gobernador, alcaldes y regidores de México
europeana:record.dc:subject: Geografía e Historia
europeana:record.dc:description: A 16th century pictographic manuscript, written in Mexico. It contains the declarations of the accused and the eye witnesses made in New Spain by Jerónimo de Valderrama, by order of Philip II between 1563-1566, to investigate the charges presented against the Viceroy, Luis de Velasco, and the other Spanish authorities that participated in the government of said Viceroy. These people and their testimonies are represented by pictographs, followed by an explanation in the Nahuatl and Castilian languages, as the scribes translated the declarations of the Indians by means of interpreters or Nahuatlatos. The drawings are an invaluable source of information on daily life in colonial Mexico: Civil and ecclesiastic buildings; construction work on houses, public works –irrigation ditches, bridges, roads-, male and female attire of the Spanish and indigenous peoples; the jobs they carried out: cultivating the land, harvesting fruit, cleaning, decorating, etc.; the utensils and instruments they used; the currency –gold and cocoa- for paying taxes; and the expedition to Florida represented by a man on horseback carrying the standard decorated with an eagle upon a prickly pear tree, followed by four principal natives in Castilian dress who accompanied the Spanish soldiers. Also known as the Codex Osuna, after its owner, the Duke of Osuna and Infantado, whose library came to the Biblioteca Nacional in 1883. It is not a codex as such, but an administrative document, removed from the voluminous record of the aforementioned visit by Valderrama for its attractive drawings; proof of this is the fact that the 39 page document conserves its original numeration (463-501).

Manuscrito pictográfico del siglo XVI, escrito en México. Contiene las declaraciones de los inculpados y testigos de la visita que efectuó en Nueva España D. Jerónimo de Valderrama, por orden de Felipe II entre 1563-1566, para investigar los cargos presentados contra el Virrey D. Luis de Velasco y demás autoridades españolas que intervinieron en el gobierno del citado Virrey. Estas personas y sus testificaciones se representan por medio de pictografías, seguidas de una explicación en nahuatl y castellano, pues los escribanos tradujeron mediante intérpretes o nahuatlatos las declaraciones de los indios. Los dibujos son una fuente inapreciable de información sobre la vida cotidiana del México colonial: edificios civiles y eclesiásticos; los trabajos de construcción de casas particulares, obras públicas –acequias, puentes, caminos-, la indumentaria masculina y femenina de españoles e indígenas; los oficios que desempeñaban: cultivo de la tierra, recolección de frutos, limpieza, adorno, etc.; utensilios e instrumentos para realizarlos; la moneda –oro o cacao- para el pago de los tributos; y la expedición a Florida representada por un hombre a caballo, portando el estandarte decorado con el águila sobre un nopal, seguido de cuatro indígenas principales, con indumentaria castellana, que acompañaban a los soldados españoles. Conocido también como Códice Osuna, por su poseedor, el Duque de Osuna e Infantado, cuya biblioteca, ingresó en la Biblioteca Nacional en 1883. No es propiamente un códice, sino un documento administrativo, desglosado, por sus atractivos dibujos, del voluminoso expediente de la citada visita del Sr. Valderrama; prueba de ello, es que el documento de 39 folios, conserva su foliación original (463-501).

europeana:record.dc:title: Corpus Pelagianum
Corpus Pelagianum
europeana:record.dc:creator: Alfonso III, Rey de Asturias y León
europeana:record.dc:subject: Geografía e Historia
europeana:record.dc:description: This is a manuscript of great importance for the knowledge of the Early Middle Ages in the western Hispanic kingdoms. It contains a series of historical texts gathered at the commission of Don Pelayo, the Bishop of Oviedo, some as noteworthy as the Chronografía by Isidore of Seville, the Crónica de Sampiro (Chronicle of Sampiro), the Gesta regum francorum or several Decreta (Decrees) by kings of Castile and León. The texts are accompanied by a considerable number of miniatures, executed with great simplicity in black and very watered down colours, that represent religious and historical figures associated with facts explained in the text. Other noteworthy decorative elements are the representation of a wind rose and tables of lineage and kinship that try to explain the family relations of the historical figures mentioned. The copy belonged to the poet Garcilaso de la Vega, who inherited it from his grandfather, Hernán Pérez de Guzmán, Lord of Batres, for whom it is known as the "Batres Codex".

Estamos ante un manuscrito de gran importancia para el conocimiento de la Alta Edad Media en los reinos occidentales hispanos. En él se contienen una serie de textos históricos mandados recopilar por el Obispo ovetense don Pelayo, algunos tan destacables como la Chronografía de Isidoro de Sevilla, la Crónica de Sampiro, la Gesta regum francorum o diversos Decreta de reyes de Castilla y León. Los textos van acompañados de un número considerable de miniaturas, realizadas con gran sencillez, en negro y con colores muy diluidos, que representan personajes religiosos e históricos relacionados con los hechos explicados en el texto. Otros elementos decorativos destacables son la representación de una rosa de los vientos y unas tablas de linajes y parentescos que tratan de explicar las relaciones familiares de los personajes históricos aludidos. El ejemplar perteneció al poeta Garcilaso de la Vega, quien lo heredó de su abuelo, Hernán Pérez de Guzmán, señor de Batres, por quien es conocido como «Códice Batres».

europeana:record.dc:title: A history of Switzerland for the Swiss people
Istoria della Svizzera pel popolo svizzero
europeana:record.dc:creator: Zschokke, Heinrich
europeana:record.dc:subject: General history of Europe Other parts of Europe
europeana:record.dc:description: The second edition of Zschokke's Swiss history was published in German in 1828. Stefano Francsini (1796-1857), one of the first seven cabinet ministers (1848-1857) translated and published the work three decades later for his Ticino countrymen

La deuxième édition de l'histoire suisse de Zschokkes est parue en 1828 sous le titre Des Schweizerlands Geschichten. Stefano Francsini (1796-1857), membre du premier Conseil fédéral et actif entre 1847 et 1857, traduisit et compléta cette oeuvre pour ses concitoyens tessinois trois décénies plus tard

Zschokkes Schweizergeschichte war unter dem Titel Des Schweizerlands Geschichten in 2. Auflage 1828 erschienen. Stefano Francsini (1796-1857), einer der sieben ersten Bundesräte (1848-1857), übersetzte und bearbeitete das Werk drei Jahrzehnte später für seine Tessiner Landsleute

europeana:record.dc:title: John Halifax, gentleman
europeana:record.dc:creator: Craik, Dinah Maria Mulock
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Dinah Maria Mulock (Mrs Craik after her 1865 marriage) turned to writing in order to support her family after the death of her mother and desertion by her father. ‘John Halifax, Gentleman’ (1856) has the archetypal Victorian self-made man as its central hero, and is cited a possible source for Samuel Smiles ‘Self Help’ (1859).

europeana:record.dc:title: Castle Rackrent and the absentee
europeana:record.dc:creator: Edgeworth, Maria
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Novelist and educational writer, Maria Edgeworth's (1768-1849) work influenced the likes of Walter Scot, Anthony Trollope, William Makepeace Thackeray and John Ruskin. ‘Castle Rackrent’ was first published in 1800 in London by the radical publisher, Joseph Johnson, and has hardly been out of print since. This edition is from the collected works, edited by Thackeray’s daughter, Anne Thackeray Ritchie. The novel owes much of its local colour to Edgeworth’s experience of collecting rents and touring the family’s Irish estate, and its narrator, Thady Quirk, is based on the family steward, John Langan. Her book ‘The Absentee’ (1812) has Lord Colambre as its hero, who trys to ameliorate the excesses of Anglo-Irish landordism.

europeana:record.dc:title: Robert Elsmere. Vol. 3.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Ward, Humphry, Mrs
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Mary Augusta Ward's (1851-1920) book 'Robert Elsmere' (1888) was one of the best-selling non-sensational novels of the 19th century. A philanthropist, Ward took up writing after she moved to London and embarked on a friendship with Henry James. The story follows the experiences of a young clergyman who meets and marries attractive intellectual, Catherine Leyburn, in Westmoreland. Returning to his parish, he is beset by religious doubts. He leaves his parish to set up the New Botherhood of Christ in the East End of London, before tragically falling victim to tubercolosis.

europeana:record.dc:title: Picturesque Holy Moscow Kremlin…
Живописный священный Кремль московский…
europeana:record.dc:subject: 690 Buildings;710 Civic & landscape art;720 Architecture;750 Painting & paintings (museums)
europeana:record.dc:description: A sweeping guide to the Moscow Kremlin covering all its monasteries, churches, cathedrals, palaces and views. Houses of Arsenal, Armoury, Ordnance-House, Senate, Patriarch’s vestiary and other buildings and rarities are described, as well as the history of their origins. Nine lithograph works of the album were designed to be glued together to make a single panorama of the Kremlin and its surroundings. If constructed, the size of the picture was expected to extend to over 6 metres in length.

Издание представляет собой оригинальное сочетание путеводителя по Московскому Кремлю, кратко описывающего все его главные памятники, и его панорамы. Предполагалось, что склеенные вместе девять литографий альбома составят единую панораму Кремля и его окрестностей более восьми аршин длиной (около 6 м).

europeana:record.dc:title: East Lynne
europeana:record.dc:creator: Wood, Henry, Mrs
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Ellen Wood (1814-1887), known as Mrs Henry Wood, began writing short fiction to alleviate her unstable financial circumstances. ‘East Lynne’ (1861) was first serialized in Ainsworth’s ‘New Monthly Magazine’ and became the most successful melodramatic novel of the period. Bentley printed over 400, 000 copies of the tale and, subsequent stage adaptations proved extremely financially lucrative for the cash strapped author. Its popularity lay in its dramatization of the hot issues of the day, such as the Matrimonial Causes Act (1857), and its use of controversial story lines like the heroine posing as governess to her own children.

europeana:record.dc:title: Griffith Gaunt : or, Jealousy. Vol. 3.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Reade, Charles
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Charles Reade (1814-1884), novelist, playwright and trader in Cremona violins, came from the landed gentry and had been expected to enter the church. He rebelled against his family's conservatiive ambitions and took to writing novels and adapting books for the stage.'The Cloister and the Hearth’ (1861) became his most famous novel, while ‘Griffith Gaunt’ (1866) proved his most controversial with its questioning of contemporary notions of sexual propriety. It's steamy final installment 'All the Year round' even prompted a disclaimer from Dickens. As a promoter of international copyright, he caused consternation when some of his own writings strayed into plagiarism. Much of his income came from stage adaptions of novels that were designed to raise issues that concerned Reade, including prison punishments.

europeana:record.dc:title: Robert Elsmere. Vol. 1.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Ward, Humphry, Mrs
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Mary Augusta Ward's (1851-1920) book 'Robert Elsmere' (1888) was one of the best-selling non-sensational novels of the 19th century. A philanthropist, Ward took up writing after she moved to London and embarked on a friendship with Henry James. The story follows the experiences of a young clergyman who meets and marries attractive intellectual, Catherine Leyburn, in Westmoreland. Returning to his parish, he is beset by religious doubts. He leaves his parish to set up the New Botherhood of Christ in the East End of London, before tragically falling victim to tubercolosis.

europeana:record.dc:title: Robert Elsmere. Vol. 2.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Ward, Humphry, Mrs
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Mary Augusta Ward's (1851-1920) book 'Robert Elsmere' (1888) was one of the best-selling non-sensational novels of the 19th century. A philanthropist, Ward took up writing after she moved to London and embarked on a friendship with Henry James. The story follows the experiences of a young clergyman who meets and marries attractive intellectual, Catherine Leyburn, in Westmoreland. Returning to his parish, he is beset by religious doubts. He leaves his parish to set up the New Botherhood of Christ in the East End of London, before tragically falling victim to tubercolosis.

europeana:record.dc:title: Beatrice : or, The unknown relatives. Vol. 1.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Sinclair, Catherine
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Catherine Sinclair (1800-1864), was an author of children’s books and adult fiction. Her most successful book was the improving work for children, ‘Holiday House’ (1839), which depicted children behaving badly. Her writing and involvement in evangelical causes sharply increased after the death of her politician father, whom she was secretary for. And her 1852 novel ‘Beatrice’ proved stridently anti-Catholic.

europeana:record.dc:title: A romance of two worlds : A novel
europeana:record.dc:creator: Corelli, Marie
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Mary Mackay (1855-1924) became Victorian England's biggest selling novelist after a failed musical career. ‘Treasures of Heaven’ (1906) sold 100,000 copies on its first day alone. ‘A Romance of Two Worlds’ (1887), her first novel, was published by Bentley against his readers' advice. The story surrounding a female pianist's encounter with the magician Heliobas, appealed to the Victorian interest in the occult.

europeana:record.dc:title: The dilemma. Vol. 1.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Chesney, George Tomkyns
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: "George Tomkyns Chesney (1830-1895) was a professional soldier in the Indian Army and military reformer. His serialised ‘The Battle of Dorking’ (1871) warned of Britain’s military weakness (in the face of a Prussian invasion) and went on to influence H.G. Well’s ‘The War of the Worlds’. ‘The Dilemma’ (1875) describes the siege of the Residency during the Indian Mutiny and comes complete with a plan of the building. "
europeana:record.dc:publisher: Edinburgh ; London : William Blackwood and Sons

europeana:record.dc:title: The dilemma. Vol. 3.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Chesney, George Tomkyns
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: "George Tomkyns Chesney (1830-1895) was a professional soldier in the Indian Army and military reformer. His serialised ‘The Battle of Dorking’ (1871) warned of Britain’s military weakness (in the face of a Prussian invasion) and went on to influence H.G. Well’s ‘The War of the Worlds’. ‘The Dilemma’ (1875) describes the siege of the Residency during the Indian Mutiny and comes complete with a plan of the building. "
europeana:record.dc:publisher: Edinburgh ; London : William Blackwood and Sons

europeana:record.dc:title: Mehalah : A story of the Salt Marshes. Vol. 1.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Baring-Gould, S
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Sabine Baring-Gould (1834-1924) was a dedicated Church of England clergyman, who penned the classic hymn ‘Onward Christian Soldiers’. Along with his religious work, he also managed to find time to write 159 books (40 of which were fiction). His parish of East Mersea, Essex (he resided there from 1871-1881) provided the inspiration for the salt-marsh setting of his most popular Victorian melodrama, ‘Mehalah’. Mehalah is the black-haired heroine, whose life ends in an untimely death by drowning at the hands of her husband. This proved to be Baring-Gould’s most reprinted work of fiction and it's dark brooding undertones even led to comparisons with ‘Wuthering Heights’.

europeana:record.dc:title: A beginner
europeana:record.dc:creator: Broughton, Rhoda
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Rhoda Broughton (1840-1920) was a prolific writer who spurned her clerical background in favour of a more sensational subject matter. Published by Bentley, her work normally explores the conflict between love and duty, and was written in a style that directly addressed the reader. ‘A Beginner’ (1894) proved a successful change from a three- to a one-volume format. It recounts the (suspiciously autobiographical) tale of a young woman who writes a controversial sensation novel.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Bondman : A new saga. Vol. 1 : The book of Stephen Orry
europeana:record.dc:creator: Caine, Thomas Henry Hall
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Author Hall Caine (1853-1931) became one Victorian England's wealthiest novelists, despite a humble background as the son of a smith and seamstress. ‘The Deemster’ (1887) was his first success and was adapted for the stage, which proved an added source of income. His novel ‘The Christian’ (1897) is reputed to be the first British novel to sell a million copies. Caine's 1890 work ‘The Bondman’ is a complex revenge/romance set in the late 18th century Isle of Man and in Iceland. Its success launched the firm of Heinemann, pioneers in publishing advertising techniques.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Bondman : A new saga. Vol. 2 : The book of Michael Sunlocks
europeana:record.dc:creator: Caine, Thomas Henry Hall
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Author Hall Caine (1853-1931) became one Victorian England's wealthiest novelists, despite a humble background as the son of a smith and seamstress. ‘The Deemster’ (1887) was his first success and was adapted for the stage, which proved an added source of income. His novel ‘The Christian’ (1897) is reputed to be the first British novel to sell a million copies. europeana:record.dc:title: Chronicles of Carlingford : The perpetual curate. Vol. 2.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Oliphant, Margaret O
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Margaret Oliphant Wilson Oliphant's (“Mrs Oliphant”) (1828-1897) first novel ‘Passages in the Life of Margaret Maitland’, attracted the attention of Charles Dickens on its publication in 1849. She wrote 98 novels in total, ranging from provincial sagas, domestic and sensation novels and gothic tales. She was also a major contributor to ‘Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine’ and was a prolific writer of non-fiction. ‘The Chronicles of Carlingford’ (1861-1876) established Mrs Oliphant’s reputation for the serio-comic depiction of provincial religious life – a sort of Trollopian Barsetshire but with God.

europeana:record.dc:title: Chronicles of Carlingford : The perpetual curate. Vol. 1.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Oliphant, Margaret O
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Margaret Oliphant Wilson Oliphant's (“Mrs Oliphant”) (1828-1897) first novel ‘Passages in the Life of Margaret Maitland’, attracted the attention of Charles Dickens on its publication in 1849. She wrote 98 novels in total, ranging from provincial sagas, domestic and sensation novels and gothic tales. She was also a major contributor to ‘Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine’ and was a prolific writer of non-fiction. ‘The Chronicles of Carlingford’ (1861-1876) established Mrs Oliphant’s reputation for the serio-comic depiction of provincial religious life – a sort of Trollopian Barsetshire but with God.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Last Days of Pompeii
europeana:record.dc:creator: Lytton, Edward Bulwer-Lytton, Baron
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Edward George Earle Lytton Bulwer (1803-1873), writer and politican, began writing novels after his mother cut his allowance following his marriage. Initially, Bulwer wrote ‘silver-fork’ novels which were always written by an aristocrat, and usually published by Henry Colburn. He wrote his first best-seller ‘Pelham’ (1828), which has similarities with Disraeli’s ‘Vivian Grey’ (1827), before turning to historical fiction. ‘The Last Days of Pompeii’ (1834) was inspired by a visit to Italy and Briullov’s painting of the same name. Set around 79 A.D., Glaucus represents Greek culture, Arbaces the Egyptian culture and Olinthus the emerging Christian one. The occult is represented by the Witch of Vesuvius.

Edward George Earle Lytton Bulwer (1803-1873), writer and politican, began writing novels after his mother cut his allowance on his marriage to Rosina Wheeler. Initially, Bulwer wrote ‘silver-fork’ novels – i.e. one written by an aristocrat, and usually published by Henry Colburn: his first best-seller was ‘Pelham’ (1828), which has similarities with Disraeli’s ‘Vivian Grey’ (1827), before he turned to historical fiction. ‘The Last Days of Pompeii’ (1834) was inspired by a visit to Italy and Briullov’s painting of the same name. Set around 79 A.D., Glaucus represents Greek culture, Arbaces the Egyptian and Olinthus the emerging Christian one. The occult is represented by the Witch of Vesuvius.

europeana:record.dc:title: The maiden & married life of Mary Powell, afterwards Mistress Milton
europeana:record.dc:creator: Manning, Anne
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Anne Manning's (1807-79) middle class, home educated roots made her publicity shy. She only ever published one book under her own name in her lifetime, the historical work, ‘Stories from the History of Italy’ (1831). ‘The Maiden and Married Life of Mary Powell’ (1849) was published anonymously in ‘Sharpe’s London Magazine’. It takes the form of a diary of Mary Powell, future wife of the poet John Milton, and employs constructed 17th century words. It was printed in archaic typography.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: London : printed for Arthur Hall & Co.

europeana:record.dc:title: Alice Lorraine : A tale of the South Downs. Vol. 2.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Blackmore, Richard Doddridge
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: This 1875 novel by 'Lorna Doon' author, Richard Doddridge Blackmore (1825-1900) was so poorly received that the writer almost gave up on fiction. ‘Alice Lorraine’ was initially serialised in ‘Blackwood’s Magazine’, March 1874-April 1875. The novel follows the trails of Hilary Lorraine, who loses £50,000 of Wellington’s army funds. His daughter, Alice, offers to marry Captain Chapman to make amends for the debt but is saved by the discovery of some lost family heirlooms. Like many of Blackmore's literary creations, Alice’s character resonates with a figure from classics, in this instance that of Antigone.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: London : Sampson Low, Marston, Low & Searle

europeana:record.dc:title: Alice Lorraine : A tale of the South Downs. Vol. 3.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Blackmore, Richard Doddridge
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: This 1875 novel by 'Lorna Doon' author, Richard Doddridge Blackmore (1825-1900) was so poorly received that the writer almost gave up on fiction. ‘Alice Lorraine’ was initially serialised in ‘Blackwood’s Magazine’, March 1874-April 1875. The novel follows the trails of Hilary Lorraine, who loses £50,000 of Wellington’s army funds. His daughter, Alice, offers to marry Captain Chapman to make amends for the debt but is saved by the discovery of some lost family heirlooms. Like many of Blackmore's literary creations, Alice’s character resonates with a figure from classics, in this instance that of Antigone.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: London : Sampson Low, Marston, Low & Searle

europeana:record.dc:title: Lorna Doone : A romance of Exmoor. Volume 3.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Blackmore, Richard Doddridge
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Classic historical romance, ‘Lorna Doone’ only sold 300 copies when it was first published in 1869. Luckily for author Richard Doddridge Blackmore (1825-1900), the cheaper 1870 one volume edition became a bestseller and has never been out of print since. Set in north-east Exmoor at the time of the 17th century Monmouth rebellion, yeoman farmer John Ridd recounts his courtship of Lorna Doone and the Ridd-Doone feud. Blackmore, a failed lawyer who made a living from fruit-farming and writing in Teddington, used his experience of natural history and dialogue and dialect in this formative regional historical romance. As a former student, many of Blackmore’s novels have a classical dimension, in this instance Lorna represents Persephone. The marriage of Lorna to John is also viewed as the submission of aristocratic power to the middle-class work ethic.

europeana:record.dc:title: Lorna Doone : A romance of Exmoor. Volume 2.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Blackmore, Richard Doddridge
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Classic historical romance, ‘Lorna Doone’ only sold 300 copies when it was first published in 1869. Luckily for author Richard Doddridge Blackmore (1825-1900), the cheaper 1870 one volume edition became a bestseller and has never been out of print since. Set in north-east Exmoor at the time of the 17th century Monmouth rebellion, yeoman farmer John Ridd recounts his courtship of Lorna Doone and the Ridd-Doone feud. Blackmore, a failed lawyer who made a living from fruit-farming and writing in Teddington, used his experience of natural history and dialogue and dialect in this formative regional historical romance. europeana:record.dc:title: The Legend of the Young Poland. Studies on the Structure of the Cultural Spirit
Legenda Młodej Polski : studja o strukturze duszy kulturalnej
europeana:record.dc:creator: Brzozowski, Stanisław (1878-1911)
europeana:record.dc:subject: 100 Philosophy and Psychology;800 Literature & Rhetoric
europeana:record.dc:description: Stanisław Brzozowski (1878-1911) was a Polish philosopher, publicist and literary critic. A socialist, he supported historical materialism and was accused of collaboration with the tsarist police in 1908. Brzozowski being an uncompromising thinker, no social circle was interested in discovering the truth of "the case of Brzozowski". Until the end of his life he was stigmatized as a traitor, which was one of the reasons he had so little influence on Polish culture and art. The other reason was that the thoughts of this philosopher were ahead of his own time. In "The Legend of Young Poland", published a year before his death, he criticized the agreeability of the art of Young Poland. He thought that it had lost its original power to revolt and accused the leading writers of Young Poland of cultivating a neo-romantic state of helplessness and sadness, as well as of lacking a well thought-out aim in their writing.

Stanisław Brzozowski (1878-1911) to polski filozof, pisarz, publicysta i krytyk literacki. Był socjalistą i zwolennikiem materializmu dziejowego. W 1908 roku został oskarżony o współpracę z carską policją. Był myślicielem bezkompromisowym, dlatego żadnemu środowisku nie zależało na dotarciu do prawdy o „sprawie Brzozowskiego”. Do końca życia był napiętnowany jako zdrajca, co stało się jednym z powodów małego oddziaływania Brzozowskiego na polską kulturę i sztukę. Drugi wynikał z faktu, że przemyślenia filozofa wyprzedzały epokę, w której żył. Brzozowski pokoleniowo był związany z epoką Młodej Polski. W "Legendzie Młodej Polski", wydanej na rok przed śmiercią, krytykował ugodowość sztuki młodopolskiej. Uważał, że zatraciła ona pierwotną siłę buntu. Zarzucał czołowym pisarzom młodopolskim kultywowanie neoromantycznego stanu niemocy i smutku, a także brak przemyślanego celu.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: Lwów : Księgarnia Polska B. Połonieckiego ; Warszawa : E. Wende

Blackmore, a failed lawyer who made a living from fruit-farming and writing in Teddington, used his experience of natural history and dialogue and dialect in this formative regional historical romance. europeana:record.dc:title: Eleanor's victory : Vol. 2.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Braddon, Mary Elizabeth
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Novelist Mary Elizabeth Braddon's (1835-1915) sensational ‘bigamy’ novel, ‘Lady Audley’s Secret’ (1862) proved a resounding success and saw her labelled as the queen of the circulating libraries. She was a rebelious force in Victorian England and her relationship with 'penny dreadful' publisher John Maxwell scandalised society at the time. Having taken up writing to escape poverty, at her peak she was earning around £2000 a novel. She published over 80 novels with unusually feisty heroine's for the time. Her leading lady in ‘Eleanor’s Victory’ (1863) even gains revenge for her father’s murder.

europeana:record.dc:title: Eleanor's victory : Vol. 1.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Braddon, Mary Elizabeth
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Novelist Mary Elizabeth Braddon's (1835-1915) sensational ‘bigamy’ novel, ‘Lady Audley’s Secret’ (1862) proved a resounding success and saw her labelled as the queen of the circulating libraries. She was a rebelious force in Victorian England and her relationship with 'penny dreadful' publisher John Maxwell scandalised society at the time. Having taken up writing to escape poverty, at her peak she was earning around £2000 a novel. She published over 80 novels with unusually feisty heroine's for the time.
